Book: Rihlat al-Sirafi (Al-Sirafi's Journey)
Author: Abu Zayd Hasan ibn Yazid al-Sirafi (died after 330 AH)
Year of Publication: 1999 AD
[Repeated metadata omitted for brevity]

Sulayman al-Sirafi was an Iranian merchant from the port of Siraf [Bandar Siraf, Iran] overlooking the Persian Gulf. He traveled to China [China] and recorded the memories of his journey in a book he authored in Arabic. Abu Zayd Hasan ibn Yazid al-Sirafi received it from him, narrated it, and refined it. We know nothing about his life or the date of his birth and death, except that he lived in the first half of the fourth century [AH]. Abu Zayd spent his childhood and adolescence in his hometown of Siraf, then migrated in 330 AH to Basra [Basra, Iraq] and resided there. He was not, in fact, a traveler or a scholar, but apparently one of those fond of such stories, of which it was easy to collect many narrations whether in his hometown Siraf or in Basra. He was an excellent example of the Arab and Persian merchants who headed to China. The French orientalist Ferrand examined what was reported from him and followed his steps in light of modern maps, finding them of high status in terms of accuracy and scientific honesty.

Introduction
Regarding trade via the sea and travel stories of Arab and Persian sailors with the lands of India [India], the Malay Archipelago [Malaysia/Indonesia], and China [China], those Arab merchants followed the ancient traditions of the southern Iraq region and the coasts of the Arabian Gulf since the Sassanian era. It is said that when the Arabs seized the port of Al-Ubullah near Basra during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab, the Muslims found Chinese ships there. Until the era of Arab sovereignty, the Persians were the most daring people in sailing the sea. It was clear since a long time ago that the Arab-Persian colony in the port of Canton [Guangzhou, China] in China had reached a limit of power whereby in the year 758 AD they laid their hands on the city, controlled it, then looted it and left the country by sea. In the late nineteenth century AD, some orientalists were lucky to find tombstones proving the visit of some Arabs to China in that ancient era in a cemetery proving the presence of a group from the people of Oman [Oman] and the Arabian Gulf. This proof was reinforced by another historical source, a book by Abu Sufyan Mahbub al-Abdi who died in the first half of the ninth century AD, where it stated that one of the Ibadi sheikhs, Abu Ubaydah Abdullah ibn al-Qasim from the people of Oman, was...

...a great scholar in his time and a well-known merchant engaged in the trade of myrrh, and he had traveled with a trade of aloe and myrrh to China. The orientalist Kratchkovsky says: But the date of that journey is unknown to us, although for several considerations it can be said that it undoubtedly occurred before the looting of Canton mentioned earlier in 758 AD. As for the other Omani merchant, he is Al-Nadr ibn Maymun who lived in Basra apparently around the eighth and ninth centuries AD, and from there he traveled to China, but we do not possess precise details about that journey of his. In any case, those Omani merchants, including the people of the Emirates [UAE], can be considered pavers of the way for other great merchants, like the author of this journey in your hands, the merchant Sulayman and his companion Ibn Wahb, whose journey was received by a geographer historian, Abu Zayd al-Sirafi, who transmitted it from them and scrutinized their narration, which is the one we are publishing now within the publications of the Cultural Foundation bearing the mentioned name. We return to what we were discussing, and we see that Arab travelers formed brief material about the countries of the Far East and others since early eras dating back to the ninth century AD, relying on what adventurous travelers circulate, who are mostly purely Arab figures who participated in some commercial travels. Ibn Rustah mentions in his book "Al-A'laq al-Nafisa" important facts about India narrated from a person unknown to historians, Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ishaq, who is different from Ibn Ishaq the well-known author of Al-Sirah and Al-Maghazi. This...

...man had spent nearly two years on the island of Qumar (i.e., Khmer, which is the old name for Cambodia [Cambodia]), and that was most likely in the early ninth century. Most European researchers among orientalists in geography believe that this man is almost the sole source for both Ibn Rustah and Ibn Khordadbeh, and he is the one from whom Yaqut quotes specific paragraphs in some entries of his book. This is regarding the sea route by Arab merchant travelers. As for if we return to their land journeys in the early eras, we will find them represented in narrations derived by Arab geographers from the mouths of other Arab travelers who passed through the land route penetrating Central Asia to China. We find that in the description provided by Tamim ibn Bahr al-Mutawwi'. As appears from his title, the man was not from the category of well-known merchants, and most likely he lived the life of Jihad and garrison duty (Murabata) in the Islamic frontiers, which extend over all the borders of the Islamic Caliphate. The mentioned person had headed to the Khaqan of the Turks (Toquz Oghuz) on a diplomatic mission as it appears. Barthold believes it dates back to the period between 760 AD - 800 AD. Yaqut cited in his book (Mu'jam al-Buldan) the most important piece of this journey through which we were able to infer the personality of the journey's author. Thus, Tamim ibn Bahr al-Mutawwi' is the first Arab geographer to mention to us the description of the land route to China. We can find the trace of the mentioned Tamim in the texts cited from him by great geographers and known travelers...

...such as Abu Dulaf, Qudamah, and also Al-Idrisi, the author of the most famous book in geography, (Nuzhat al-Mushtaq fi Ikhtiraq al-Afaq), and even Ibn Khordadbeh and Yaqut as we mentioned previously. Tamim is the first Arab to give us important information about the Toquz Oghuz based primarily on direct personal information he witnessed himself. He describes for us the capital of the Toquz Oghuz (Qamju) near (Turfan) [Turpan, China] and mentions information about the rain stone among the Turks, and so on.

Sulayman the Merchant
We return to the author of this journey of ours, the merchant Sulayman, which Abu Zayd al-Sirafi received from him, narrated, and refined. The mentioned person is one of the ancient travelers known for their strange journeys and interesting narrations about the countries they visited. We know nothing about his life except what reached us from the narration he mentioned about his journey, which mostly dates back to around the year 237 AH. He traveled repeatedly for the purpose of trade to India and China. The French orientalist Ferrand examined what was reported from him and followed his steps in light of modern maps, finding them of high status in terms of accuracy and scientific honesty. He says: He is the best example of Arab and Persian merchants who headed to China. He sailed from (Siraf) [Bandar Siraf, Iran] to (Muscat) [Muscat, Oman] on the Arabian Gulf, and from there to (Kulam) [Kollam, India] on the Malabar Coast [India], then passed through the (Palk) Strait north of the island of (Ceylon) [Sri Lanka], then crossed the Bay of Bengal reaching the island of (Lanjabalus) (one of the Nicobar Islands [India]), then advanced to (Kalah Barh) on the western Malay coast [Malaysia], and passed from there to the island of (Tioman) [Malaysia] located southwest of (Malacca) [Malaysia], and from there to Cape...

...St. James near (Saigon) [Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam], and from there to the island of (Hainan) [China], crossing the strait separating it from the land of China to reach the port of (Khanfu) or modern (Canton) [Guangzhou, China] in China. The sea journey from (Muscat) to China used to take more than four months. Sulayman did not limit his description to mentioning the stages and estimating distances in days and sometimes in parasangs, but also left a vivid description of the coasts, islands, various ports, cities and their inhabitants, crops, products, and trade goods. It was also proven that the information he cited about (Canton) is characterized by detail and accuracy. Kratchkovsky says in discussing the attribution of those journeys to Sulayman the Merchant: Given the lack of information about Sulayman himself, some major Sinologists such as Yule and Pelliot doubted the attribution of the stories to him. Another opinion also appeared seeing that these stories belong to an Arab who visited India. However, Ferrand drew attention to the fact that Ibn al-Faqih explicitly attributes the stories to Sulayman, and therefore the issue of his authorship of them is beyond any doubt. Added to the stories attributed to Sulayman, twenty years after the mentioned journey, was another traveler, Ibn Wahb, whose lineage goes back to Quraysh. He was one of the wealthy notables and left his city Basra when it fell into the hands of the Zanj rebels in the year 257 AH. He decided to undertake a long journey from Siraf to China, and success was his ally as he reached the capital of China, which was then (Khamdan) [Xi'an, China]. His description has special importance because after that, in the year 264 AH, the...

...Arab colony in (Canton) was eliminated as a result of internal wars, thus cutting direct links between the Arabs and China. The last port reached by Arab ships became (Mina Kalah) and Kalah Barh on the Malay Peninsula. Contact with China was not renewed until the second half of the thirteenth century AD. The stories of Sulayman and Ibn Wahb were recorded at the beginning of the tenth century AD by Abu Zayd al-Hasan al-Sirafi from the people of Basra, who gave them the form known to us now. The mentioned Al-Sirafi was not in fact a traveler or a scholar, but was apparently one of those fond of such stories, of which it was easy to collect many narrations whether in his hometown (Siraf) or in (Basra). Al-Mas'udi met him in the year 303 AH and benefited from him regarding the narration of Ibn Wahb mentioned in this journey of ours. The manuscript of Abu Zayd al-Sirafi's journey that reached us in a unique single copy is the one present in the National Library in Paris [France]. Copyists added an introduction to it that has absolutely no relation to the book's contents. Complicating the problem further is that the manuscript bears a title completely inappropriate and inconsistent with the book's subject, which is the title (Silsilat al-Tawarikh / Chain of Histories). Reinaud's edition was issued in 1811 AD bearing this title. Due to the importance of the journey of the merchant Sulayman, this work caught the attention of major orientalists in the eighteenth century, so a French translation of it appeared since 1718 AD. This translation led to its embezzlement and the addition of things by some adventurers who attributed it to...

...themselves. The credit for studying this journey and editing its texts goes to the French orientalist Reinaud, then after him came the French orientalist also Ferrand who re-edited and translated it with a methodology worthy of mention. We have benefited from both editions and tried to present it in this mold with the addition of some necessary comments compatible with this journey and in terms of heritage character as the reader will see. And with God is success.

[The First Book] This is a book containing the chain of histories, countries, seas, types of fish, astronomy, wonders of the world, measurement of countries and the inhabited parts thereof, wild animals, and other wonders. It is a precious book.
Chapter on the Sea that is between the lands of India and Sindh

and Ghuz and Maghuz (1), and Mount Qaf, and the lands of Serendib [Sri Lanka]. And Abu Hubaysh opened [?], who is the man who lived two hundred and fifty years and in some years stayed in Al-Maghuz. Abu Hubaysh the wise traveler saw, so he was brought to the sea and shown (2) a fish like a sail (3). Sometimes it raises its head [out of the water] (4) so you see it like a huge thing. Sometimes it blows water from its mouth like a great minaret. If the sea calms, the fish gather, so it corrals them with its tail, then opens its mouth, and the fish are seen sinking into its belly as if sinking (5) into a well. The ships that are in the sea fear it, so they ring bells at night like the bells of Christians for fear that it might lean on the ship and drown it. In this sea [is a fish we caught] (6) whose length is twenty cubits. We split its belly and took out from it also a fish of its kind, then we split the belly of the second and found inside its belly one like it. All this is alive and wriggling, resembling each other in form.

For this large fish called Al-Wal (Whale) (1), despite the greatness of its creation, there is a fish called Al-Lashak (2) whose length is about a cubit. If this [large] fish becomes tyrannical and aggressive and harms the fish in the sea, this small fish is empowered over it. It settles at the root of its ear (3) and does not leave it until it kills it. It sticks (4) to the ship, so this large fish does not approach the ship out of fear of the small one. In this sea also is a fish whose face resembles the face of a human that flies over the water; the name of this fish is Al-Mij (5). And another fish from under the water...

...watches it until it falls, then swallows it. This fish is called Al-'Anqatus (1). All fish eat one another.
[Sea of Harkand]
The third sea is the Sea of Harkand (2). Between it and the Sea of Dalarwi (3) are many islands said to be one thousand nine hundred islands. They are the separation between these two seas, Dalarwi and Harkand. These islands are ruled by a woman. In these islands, ambergris of great quantity falls; a piece falls like a house (4) or similar. This ambergris grows at the bottom of the sea like a plant. When the sea's agitation intensifies, it casts it from its bottom like mushrooms and truffles. These islands ruled by the woman are populated with coconut palms (5). The distance...

...between island and island is two (1), three, or four parasangs. All of them are populated with people and coconut palms. Their wealth is cowrie shells (Wada') (2). This queen hoards cowrie shells in her treasuries. It is said that the people of this island (3) are the most skilled, so much so that they make a shirt woven complete with two sleeves, two gores (4), and a collar. They build ships and houses and do all work in this manner of craftsmanship. The cowrie shells come to them on the surface of the water containing a spirit (living organism). So a palm branch from coconut palms is taken and thrown on the water surface, and the cowrie shells cling to it. They call it Al-Kabtah (5).

The last of these islands is Serendib (1) [Sri Lanka] in the Sea of Harkand. It is the head of all these islands. They call them Al-Dubayjat (2). In Serendib (3) there are pearl diving places; its sea is all around it. In its land is a mountain called Al-Rahun (4) [Adam's Peak] on which Adam, peace be upon him, descended. His footprint is in a rock (5) at the top of this mountain sunken into the stone: at the top of this mountain is a single footprint. It is said that he, peace be upon him, took another step into the sea. It is said: This footprint on top of the mountain is about seventy cubits. Around this mountain are mines of precious stones: red and yellow ruby (sapphire) and sky-blue (6). In this island there are two kings. It is a great, wide island containing aloe wood, gold, and gems. In its sea are pearls and the shank (chank shell), which is here...

...(the trumpet) into which one blows, among what they store. In this sea, when sailing to Serendib, there are islands not many, but they are vast and uncontrollable. Among them: an island called Al-Ramni (1) [Sumatra, Indonesia] containing several kings. Its width is said to be eight hundred or nine hundred parasangs. In it are gold mines, and in it are mines called Fansur (2) [Barus, Indonesia] from which comes good camphor. Adjacent to these islands are islands following them, among them: an island called Al-Niyan (3) [Nias, Indonesia]. They have much gold and their food is coconut, which they use as condiment and oil. If one of them wants to marry, he is not married unless with the skull (top of the head) of a man from their enemies. If he kills two, he marries two; likewise, if he kills fifty, he marries fifty women with fifty skulls. The reason for that is that their enemies are many, so whoever is more daring in killing is more desired among them. In these islands, meaning Al-Ramni, are many elephants, and in it is Brazilwood (4)...

and Al-Khayzuran (bamboo) «1». In it are: a people who eat men, and it opens onto two seas: Harkand [Bay of Bengal] and Salahit [Straits of Malacca] «2». After this are islands called Lanjbalus [Nicobar Islands] «3», and in them are many people, the men and women among them are naked, except that on the private parts of the woman is a leaf from the leaves of trees. If ships pass by them, they come to them in small and large boats and trade with their people ambergris and coconut for iron and what they need of clothing, because there is no heat or cold among them. Beyond these are two islands with a sea between them called «4» Andaman [Andaman Islands] «5». Their people eat men alive; they are black, with peppercorn hair, hideous faces and eyes, long legs, and the foot-span «6» of one of them is like a cubit [meaning...

its mention] naked. They have no boats; if they had them, they would have eaten everyone who passed by them. Perhaps ships slow down in the sea and their travel is delayed due to the wind, so the water in the ships runs out, and they approach these people to seek water. Sometimes they capture some of them, but mostly they escape. After this island are mountains not on the route; it is said: in them are silver mines, but they are uninhabited. Not every ship that wants them finds them. A mountain among them called Al-Khushnami «1» indicated it. A ship passed by it and they saw the mountain and headed for it. When morning came, they descended to it in a boat to gather firewood. They lit a fire, and the silver melted, so they knew it was a mine. They carried what they wanted from it, but when they boarded, the sea became rough against them, so they threw away all that they had taken from it. Then people equipped themselves after that for this mountain, but they did not know it. Like this in the sea are many uncounted islands that are forbidden, unknown to the sailors; some of them they are unable to reach. Perhaps a white cloud is seen in this sea shading the ships, and a long, thin tongue extends from it until that tongue sticks to the sea water. Then the sea water boils because of it like a tornado (waterspout). If the tornado overtakes the ship, it swallows it. Then that cloud rises and rains a rain containing the filth of the sea. I do not know if the cloud draws water from the sea or how this is. Every sea of these seas has a wind that rages in it, stirring it and agitating it until it boils like the boiling of pots, casting what is in it onto the islands within it, and breaking...

the ships, and casting out dead fish, huge and great. Perhaps it casts out rocks and mountains just as a bow casts an arrow. As for the Sea of Harkand [Bay of Bengal], it has a wind other than this, between the West and Banat Na'sh (Ursa Major/North), and the sea boils because of it like the boiling of pots, and it casts out much ambergris. The deeper the sea and the further its bottom, the better the ambergris. This sea—I mean Harkand—when its waves become great, you see it like fire burning. In this sea are fish called Al-Lakhm «1» (sharks/sea monsters), which is a beast that swallows men «2». In [their hands is all this] «3», so goods decrease. Among the reasons for the scarcity of goods is a fire that perhaps occurred in (Khanfu) [Guangzhou, China] «4», which is the port of the ships and the gathering place of the trades of...

the Arabs and the people of China [China], so the fire consumes the goods. That is because their houses there are of wood and split bamboo «1». Among the reasons for that is that the departing and arriving ships break, or they are looted, or they are forced to stay for a long time, so they sell the goods in lands other than the lands of the Arabs. Perhaps the wind throws them to Yemen [Yemen] or elsewhere, so they sell the goods there. Perhaps they prolong the stay to repair their ships and other causes. Sulayman the Merchant mentioned that in (Khanfu) [Guangzhou], which is the gathering place of merchants, is a Muslim man whom the Ruler of China appoints to judge between the Muslims who head to that region. The King of China desires that. If it is the Eid, he leads the Muslims in prayer, delivers the sermon, and prays for the Sultan of the Muslims. The Iraqi merchants do not deny anything of his authority in his judgments and his knowledge of the truth and what is in the Book of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, and the rulings of Islam. As for the places they arrive at and ascend to, they mentioned that most of the Chinese ships load from Siraf [Bandar Siraf, Iran] «2» and that goods are carried from Basra [Basra, Iraq], Oman [Oman], and elsewhere to Siraf, then packed into the Chinese ships at Siraf. That is due to the frequency of waves in this sea and the shallowness of the water in places of it. The distance between Basra and Siraf by water is one hundred and twenty parasangs. When the goods are packed at Siraf, they fetch fresh water from there, and they 'snatch' (khatifu)—and this is a term...

used by the people of the sea meaning they set sail—to a place called Muscat [Muscat, Oman] «1», which is the last administration of Oman. The distance from Siraf to it is about two hundred parasangs. In the east of this sea, between Siraf and Muscat among the lands, is the Coast of Banu al-Saffaq «2» and the Island of Ibn Kawan [Qeshm/Lavan] «3». In the west of this sea are the Mountains of Oman, and in them is the place called Al-Durdur [Strait of Hormuz/Musandam] «4», which is a narrow pass between two mountains «5» traversed by small ships but not traversed by Chinese ships. In it are the two mountains called Kusayr and Uwayr «6», and only a little of them appears above the water. When we pass «7» the mountains, we come to a place called...

Sohar [Sohar, Oman] «1» of Oman. Fresh water is fetched from Muscat from a well there. There is [a mountain] «2» there with sheep belonging to the land of Oman. The ships set sail ('snatch') from there to the land of India [India] and head to Kulam Mali [Kollam, India] «3». The distance from Muscat to Kulam Mali is a month with moderate wind. In Kulam Mali is a garrison «4» belonging to the land of Kulam Mali where Chinese ships come. It has fresh water from wells. One thousand dirhams are taken from the Chinese [ships], and from other ships between ten dinars to [twenty] «5» dinars. Between Muscat and Kulam Mali and Harkand is about a month. At Kulam Mali they fetch fresh water, then the ships set sail to the Sea of Harkand [Bay of Bengal]. When they pass it, they come to a place called Lanjbalus [Nicobar Islands] «6». They do not understand the language of the Arabs nor what the merchants know of languages. They are a people who do not...

wear clothes, white, beardless «1». They mentioned that they did not see women among them «2». That is because their men come out to them from the island in skiffs hollowed out from a single piece of wood, carrying coconuts, sugar cane, and bananas. Coconut drink: it is a white drink; if drunk after an hour, it is taken from the coconut and is sweet like honey. If left for an hour, it becomes wine «3», and if it remains for days, it becomes vinegar. They sell that for iron. Perhaps a little ambergris falls to them, so they sell it for pieces of iron. They only trade by signaling, hand to hand, since they do not understand the language. They are skilled in swimming; perhaps they steal the iron from the merchants and give them nothing. Then the ships set sail to a place called Kalah Bar [Kedah, Malaysia] «4». The kingdom and the coast are all called Kalah Bar. It is the Kingdom of Zabaj [Srivijaya] «5» on the right from...

the land of India, united by a king. Their clothing is waist wrappers (Fuwat) «1»; the noble «2» and the lowly among them wear a single waist wrapper. They fetch water there from fresh wells, and they prefer well water over spring and rain water. The distance between Kulam, which is near Harkand, to Kalah Bar is a month. Then the ships travel to a place called Batuma [Tioman Island, Malaysia] «3», and in it is fresh water for whoever wants it; the distance to it is ten days. Then the ships set sail to a place called Kadranj [Phan Rang, Vietnam] «4», ten days. In it is fresh water for whoever wants it. Likewise are the islands of India; if wells are dug in them, fresh water is found. In it is a high mountain, and perhaps fugitive slaves and thieves are in it «5».

Then the ships travel «1» to a place called Sanf [Champa/Central Vietnam] «2», a journey of ten days. In it is fresh water, and from it comes the Sanfi Oud (aloeswood). It has a king, and they are a brown people; each one of them wears two waist wrappers. When they have fetched fresh water from there, they set sail to a place called Sandar Fulat [Con Dao Islands, Vietnam] «3», which is an island in the sea. The distance to it is ten days. In it is fresh water. Then the ships set sail to a sea called Sanji [South China Sea] «4», then to the Gates of China «5». These are mountains in the sea; between every two mountains is a gap through which the ships pass [then to China]. If Allah grants safety from Sandar Fulat «6», the ships set sail to China [China] in a month, except that the mountains through which the ships pass take a journey of seven days.

When the ship passes the Gates and enters the estuary «1», it comes to fresh water at the place where it anchors in the land of China. It is called Khanfu [Guangzhou]: a city. The rest of China has fresh water from fresh rivers, valleys, garrisons, and markets in every region. In it are high tide and low tide twice in the day and night, except that the high tide in what follows Basra to the Island of Banu Kawan «2» is when the moon is in the middle of the sky [and when it is opposite the middle of the sky] «3», and the low tide is at the rising of the moon and at its setting. But the high tide in the region of China to near the Island of Banu Kawan «4» is when the moon rises; when it is in the middle of the sky, the water ebbs, and when it sets, there is high tide, and when it is opposite the middle of the sky, it ebbs. [Island of Maljan] They mentioned: that in an island called Maljan «5», between Sarandib [Sri Lanka] and Kalah [Kedah], and that is among the lands of India in the east of the sea, are a people of the Blacks (Sudan), naked...

if they find a human from other than their lands, they hang him upside down, cut him up, and eat him raw. Their number is many, and they are on one island. They have no king. Their food is fish, bananas, coconuts «1», and sugar cane. They have [places they shelter in] «2» resembling thickets and marshes. [Water Locust] They mentioned that in the region of the sea is a small flying fish that flies over the face of the water called the Water Locust (Jarad al-Ma'). And they mentioned that in the region of the sea is a fish that comes out until it climbs the coconut tree and drinks the water inside the coconut, then returns to the sea «3». [The Kohl Animal] They mentioned: that in the sea is an animal resembling the crab; if it comes out of the sea, it becomes a stone. He said: Kohl is made from it for some ailments of the eye. [Mountain of Fire] They mentioned that near Zabaj [Srivijaya] «4» is a mountain called the Mountain of Fire (Volcano) which cannot be approached. Smoke appears from it by day, and a flame of fire by night. From its bottom exits a cold fresh spring and a hot fresh spring «5». The clothing «6» of the people of China, small and large, is silk, in winter...

and summer. As for the kings, it is fine silk, and for those below them, it is according to their status. When it is winter, the man wears «1» two pairs of trousers «2», three, four, five, and more than that according to what is possible for them. Their intention is only to keep their lower parts warm due to the excess of dampness and their fear of it. As for the summer, they wear a single shirt of silk and the like. They do not wear turbans. Their food is rice; perhaps they cook a sauce (Kushan) «3» with it and pour it over the rice and eat it. As for their kings, they eat wheat bread and meat from all animals, pigs, and others. They have fruits: apples, peaches, citrons, pomegranates, quinces, pears, bananas, sugar cane, melons, figs, grapes, cucumbers, snake melons, nabq (lotus jujube), walnuts, almonds, hazelnuts «4», pistachios, plums, apricots, service berries (Ghubayra) «5», and coconuts. They do not have many palm trees, except for a palm tree in the house of one of them. Their drink is wine made from rice. There is no grape wine in their lands, nor is it brought to them, nor do they know it or drink it. From rice, vinegar is made...

and wine and confection (natif) «1» and what resembles that. They have no cleanliness, and they do not clean themselves with water when they defecate; rather, they wipe that with Chinese paper. They eat carrion and what resembles it of what the Majus (Zoroastrians/Pagans) do, for their religion resembles the religion of the Majus. Their women uncover their heads and place combs in them; perhaps there are twenty combs of ivory and other things in a woman's head «2». The men cover their heads with something resembling caps. Their law regarding thieves is that the thief is killed if caught «3». News of the Lands of India and China also and their Kings: The people of India and China are agreed that the counted kings of the world are four. The first whom they count of the four: The King of the Arabs, and this is a consensus among them with no difference among them, that he is the king of the greatest of kings, the most abundant in wealth, the most splendid in beauty, and that he is the king of the great religion above which there is nothing. Then the King of China counts himself after [the King Balhara], the King of the Arabs. Then the King of the Romans (Byzantines), then Balhara «4», the King of Those with Pierced Ears...

As for this Balhara [Rashtrakuta Dynasty], he is the most noble of India, and they acknowledge his nobility. Every king of the kings of India is independent in his kingdom, except that they acknowledge this one. If his messengers arrive at the other kings, they bow to his messengers out of reverence for him. He is a king who gives gifts as the Arabs do. He has many horses and elephants and much wealth. His wealth consists of dirhams called Tatariyyah «1»; the weight of each dirham is a dirham and a half by the minting of the King. His date is in the year of the reign «2» of the one who was before him, not like the year of the Arabs from the era of the Prophet, peace be upon him; rather, their dating is by the kings. Their kings live long; perhaps one of them reigns for fifty years. The people of the Kingdom of Balhara claim: the duration of their reign and their lives in kingship is only long because of their love for the Arabs. Among the kings, there is none with a stronger love for the Arabs than him, and likewise are the people of his kingdom. Balhara is a name for every king of theirs, like Kisra (Chosroes) and the like; it is not a personal name. The King Balhara and his land: its beginning is the seacoast, and it is a land called Al-Kumkum [Konkan Coast] «3» connected on the land to China. Around him are many kings who fight him, yet he prevails over them. [King of Al-Jurz] Among them is a king called the King of Al-Jurz [Gujarat/Gurjara-Pratihara] «4». He has a large army; no one in India has the like of his cavalry. He is an enemy of the Arabs, yet he acknowledges that the King of the Arabs is the greatest of...

kings, and no one in India is more hostile to Islam than him. He is on a tongue of the land. Their wealth is great, and their camels and livestock are many. They trade with silver dust (Tibr). It is said that they have mines, and there is no place in the land of India safer from theft «1» than it. [King of Al-Tafiq] To his side is the King of Al-Tafiq, who has a small kingdom. Their women are white, the most beautiful women of India. He is a king at peace with those around him due to the smallness of his army, and he loves the Arabs like the love of Balhara. [The King Rahmi] Next to these is a king called Darharum (Dharma) «2» [Pala Empire]. The King of Al-Jurz fights him. He has no nobility in kingship, and he also fights Balhara just as the King of Al-Jurz fights him. This Rahmi [Rahmi] has a larger army than the King Balhara, the King of Al-Jurz, and the Taqi (Tafiq) «3». It is said: when he goes out to fight, he goes out with about fifty thousand elephants «4». He only goes out in winter because elephants cannot endure thirst, so he can only go out in winter. It is said: the laundrymen of his army are about ten thousand to fifteen thousand. In his land are clothes the like of which no one has; a garment of it enters into a ring due to its fineness and beauty. It is of cotton, and we have seen some of it. That which circulates in his land is Cowrie shells (Wada'), which is the 'eye' of the land, meaning its money.

In his land are gold, silver, aloeswood, and Samar (Sable/Fly-whisk) «1» clothes from which fly-whisks «2» are made. [The Rhinoceros Animal] In his land is the marked Bashan, which is the Karkaddan (Rhinoceros). It has a single horn on the front of its forehead. In its horn is a mark «3», a picture of its creation like the picture of a human in its representation. The horn is all black and the picture is white in the middle of it. This Rhinoceros is smaller than the elephant in creation; it is closer to blackness. It resembles the buffalo. It is strong; no animal has strength like its strength. It has no joint in its knee or in its foreleg; from its foot to its armpit, it is one piece. The elephant flees from it. It ruminates as cows and camels ruminate. Its meat is halal; we have eaten it. It is abundant in this kingdom in their thickets, and it is in the rest of the lands of India, except that the horns of this one are better. Perhaps there is in the horn the picture of a man, [the picture of a peacock], the picture of a fish, and other pictures. The people of China make belts from them. The belt «4» reaches two thousand dinars and three thousand and more in the land of China, according to the beauty of the picture. All this is bought from the land of Dahram (Rahmi) with Cowrie shells, which is the 'eye' (money) of the land.

[King of the Kashbin] After him is an interior king having no sea called the King of the Kashbin [Kashmir?] «1». They are a white people with pierced ears. They have beauty, and they are people of the desert and mountains. [King of Al-Qiranj] After him is a sea upon which is a king called Al-Qiranj «2». He is a poor, boastful king. Much ambergris falls to him. He has elephant tusks, and he has pepper which is eaten fresh due to its scarcity. [Other Kings] After this are many kings whose number only Allah, Blessed and Exalted, knows. Among them is Al-Mujah [Yunnan/Nanzhao?] «3». They are a white people resembling the Chinese in dress. They have much musk, and in their lands are white mountains; nothing is taller than them. They fight many kings around them. The musk that is in their lands is of high quality. [Kings of Al-Mabad] Beyond them are the Kings of Al-Mabad. Their cities are many. They are towards where Al-Mujah is, and more [numerous] than Al-Mujah, except that the Mabad «4» are more similar to the Chinese than them. They have eunuch servants like the Chinese who are workers over them. Their lands connect to the lands of China, and they are at peace with the Ruler of China, except that they do not listen to him. The Mabad have messengers to the King of China every year and gifts, and likewise, the King...

of China gives gifts to him. Their lands are vast. When the messengers of Al-Mabad enter the lands of China, they are guarded for fear that they might conquer their lands due to their large numbers, and there is nothing between them and the lands of China except mountains and passes. It is said that the King of China has more than two hundred main cities (mothers of cities). Each city has a king and a eunuch «1». Under each city are cities. Among their cities is Khanfu [Guangzhou], which is the port of ships; under it are twenty cities. It is only called a city if it has the Jadim. [The Jadim] The Jadim «2» is like the trumpet blown into. It is long, and its thickness is what two palms can gather together. It is coated with the medicine (lacquer/varnish) of the Chinese women «3». Its length is three or four cubits, and its head is thin, the size of what a man can put in his mouth. Its sound travels about a mile. Each city has four. At every gate of it are five Jadims blown at times of the night and day. At every [gate] «4» of a city are ten drums beaten with it. This is only done so that their obedience to the King is known, and by it, they know the times of the night and day. They have signs and weights for the hours. [Transactions of the People of China] Their transactions are with Fulus (copper coins), and their treasuries are like the treasuries of kings, and no king has Fulus other than them. It is the 'eye' (money) of the land. They have gold, silver...

pearls, brocade, and silk; all that is abundant among them, except that these are goods, and the Fulus are the currency. Ivory, frankincense, copper ingots, and Dhabl «1» from the sea—which is the skins of the backs of turtles—are brought to them. And this Bashan which we described «2», which is the Rhinoceros; they make belts from its horns. Their animals are many. They have no Arabian horses, but others. They have donkeys and many camels having two humps. They have good porcelain (Ghadar); cups are made from it with the thinness of glass bottles, the light of water is seen in it, and it is of clay «3». [Treatment of Merchants by the People of China] When the sailors enter from the sea, the Chinese seize their goods, put them in houses, and guarantee the protection for six months until the last of the sailors enter. Then three out of every ten are taken, and the rest is handed over to the merchants. What the Sultan needs, he takes at the highest price and pays promptly, and no injustice is done in it. Among what they take is camphor—the Mann «4» for fifty Fakujj, and the Fakujj is a thousand Fulus. This camphor, if the Sultan does not take it, is worth half the price outside. [Custom of the People of China in Death] If a man from the people of China dies, he is not buried until the day he died...

on the like of it in the following year. They put him in a coffin and leave him in their homes. They put lime «1» on him, so it absorbs his water and he remains. The kings are put in aloe and camphor. They weep over their dead for three years. Whoever does not weep is beaten with wood; likewise the women and men, and they say: 'Your dead did not sadden you.' They are buried in a tomb like the tomb of the Arabs. They do not cut off food from him; they claim that he eats and drinks. That is because they place food near him at night, and in the morning they find nothing of it, so they say he has eaten. They do not cease weeping and feeding as long as the dead is in their house, so they become impoverished over their dead; no cash or estate remains for them unless they have spent it on him. Before this, they used to bury the king and what he owned of his household tools, clothes, and belts—and their belts amount to much money—but they have abandoned that now. That is because some of their dead were exhumed and what was with them was taken. [Care of the People of China for Learning Calligraphy and Writing] The poor and the rich of the people of China, and the small and the large, learn calligraphy and writing. [Names of their Kings and their Custom in Kingship] The name of their kings is according to the status and the size of the cities. Whoever is of a small city, its king is called Tusanj «2», and the meaning of Tusanj is 'Establisher of the City'. And whatever...

was from a city like Khanfu [Guangzhou, China], its king is Qasim Difu, and the eunuch is called Al-Tuqam, and their eunuchs are castrated from among them. The Chief Judge is called Laqshi Mamkun (1) and similar names which we cannot accurately record. None of them reigns for less than forty years; they say: 'Experience has seasoned him.' As for the lesser kings, if one of them sits, he sits in his city on a chair in a great hall, and before him is a chair, and books containing the judgments of the people are presented to him. Behind the king is a standing man called Linjun (2); if the king slips in something he orders and makes a mistake, he [Linjun] corrects him. They do not pay attention to the speech of anyone who presents [a petition] to them unless he writes it in a book. Before the owner of the story [petitioner] enters upon the king, a man standing at the door of the house looks into his book; he looks into the books of the people, and if there is an error in them, he returns it. No one writes to the king except a scribe who knows the judgment. The scribe writes in the book: 'Written by So-and-so son of So-and-so.' If there is an error in it, the blame returns to the scribe, and he is beaten with wood. The king does not sit for judgment until he eats and drinks so that he does not make mistakes. The stipends of every king are from the treasury of his city. As for the Greatest King, he is not seen except every ten months; he says: 'If people see me, they will belittle me, and leaderships are not established except with haughtiness, because the common people do not know justice, so it is necessary to use haughtiness with them so we are magnified in their eyes.'

There is no land tax (kharaj) on their land, but there is a poll tax (jizya) on the male heads according to what they see of conditions. If there is an Arab or other [foreigner] among them, a tax is taken from his wealth to safeguard his wealth. If prices rise (1), the Sultan brings out food from his treasuries and sells it cheaper than the market price, so no inflation remains among them. What enters the treasury is only from the poll tax on their heads. I think that what enters the treasury of Khanfu [Guangzhou] every day is fifty thousand dinars, although it is not the greatest of their cities. The King exclusively controls from the minerals salt, and a herb which they drink with hot water. It is sold in every city for great money, and it is called Al-Sakh (2) [Tea]. It has more leaves than clover (3) and is slightly better [scented], and it has bitterness. Water is boiled and sprinkled upon it; it benefits them for everything. All that enters the treasury is the poll tax, salt, and this herb. In every city there is something called Al-Dara, which is a bell on the head of [the residence of] the king of that city, tied with a cord extending on the surface of the road for all the common people. Between the king and it is about a parasang. If the extended cord is moved the slightest movement, the bell moves...

...so whoever has a grievance moves this cord, and the bell moves from it over the head of the king, so he is permitted to enter until he reports his case himself and explains his grievance. All the cities have the like of that. Whoever wants to travel from one of them to another takes two documents from the king and from the eunuch (1). As for the king's document, it is for the road, with the name of the man, the name of who is with him, his age and the age of who is with him, and from which tribe he is. All who are in the lands of China, of its people, the Arabs, and others, must belong to something by which they are known. As for the eunuch's document, it is regarding the money and the goods he has with him. That is because on their road are guard posts (2) who look into the two documents. If a traveler arrives at them, they write: 'So-and-so son of So-and-so the Such-and-such arrived at us on such day, such month, and such year, and with him is such and such,' so that nothing of the man's money nor his goods goes to waste. So whenever something of it is lost or he dies, it is known how it was lost, and it is returned to him or to his heirs after him. 

[Fairness of the People of China in Transactions]

The people of China are fair in transactions and the Divan. If a man has a debt against another man, he writes a document against him, and the one who owes the debt also writes a document, and marks it with a mark between his middle finger and index finger. Then the two documents are gathered and folded together, then written upon their separation, then separated, so the one who owes the debt is given his document with his acknowledgment. So whenever one of them denies his creditor, it is said to him: 'Bring your document.' If the one who owes the debt claims he owes nothing and presents his document with his handwriting...

...and his mark, and the document of the rights holder is lost, it is said to the denier who owes the right: 'Bring a document that this right is not upon you.' So whenever the rights holder whom you denied proves it against you, upon you are twenty strokes of wood on the back, and twenty thousand Fakkuj of Fils (copper coins). The Fakkuj is a thousand Fils; that amounts to nearly two thousand dinars. The twenty strokes of wood contain his death. So hardly anyone in the lands of China gives this of himself for fear of loss of life and wealth, and we did not see anyone agree to that. They are fair among themselves, and no right is lost for anyone, and they do not transact with witness or oath. If a man goes bankrupt with the money of a group, and the creditors imprison him with their money at the Sultan's, his acknowledgment is taken. If he stays in prison for a month, the Sultan brings him out and proclaims about him: 'This So-and-so son of So-and-so went bankrupt with the money of So-and-so son of So-and-so. If he has a deposit with anyone, or has real estate or slaves or what covers his debt, let it be brought out.' In every month he is beaten with strokes of wood on his buttocks, because he stayed in prison eating and drinking while having money. He is beaten whether someone acknowledges money for him or does not acknowledge for him; he is beaten in any case. It is said: 'You have no work except taking people's rights and going off with them.' And it is said to him: 'Manage the rights of these people.' If he has no stratagem and it is proven to the Sultan that he has nothing, the creditors are called and given from the treasury of the Baghbun (1), who is the Greatest King. He was named Baghbun, and its meaning is Son of Heaven, and we call him Al-Maghbun. Then it is proclaimed: 'Whoever trades with this one, upon him is death.' So hardly any money is lost for anyone. And if it is known that he has...

...money with someone and the depositary does not acknowledge the money, he is killed with wood. Nothing is said to the owner of the money, so the money is taken and divided among the creditors, and no trade is done [with him] after that.

[The Stone Mentioning Medicines]

They have an erected stone ten cubits long, written on it by carving into the stone the mention of medicines and diseases: such disease, its medicine is such. If the man is poor, he is given the price of the medicine from the treasury. There is no land tax on their estates, but it is taken from the heads according to their wealth and estates. If a male is born to someone, his name is written with the Sultan. When he reaches eighteen years, the poll tax is taken from him. If he reaches eighty years, the poll tax is not taken from him, and he is provided for from the treasury. They say: 'We took from him as a young man and provide (1) for him as an old man.' In every city there is a school (Kuttab) and a teacher teaching the poor, and their children eat from the treasury. Their women have uncovered hair, and the men cover their heads. In it is a village called Taywa in the mountain; they are short, and every short person in the lands of China is attributed to it. The people of China are people of beauty, height, and pure whiteness tinged with redness. They have the blackest hair, and their women shear their hair.

[Mention of the Lands of India]

As for the lands of India [India], if a man makes a claim against another involving death, it is said to the claimant: 'Will you carry the fire?' He says: 'Yes.' So a piece of iron is heated...

...intensely until fire appears in it. Then it is said to him: 'Extend your hand.' Seven leaves of a tree of theirs are placed on his hand, then the iron is placed on his hand over the leaves. Then he walks with it back and forth until he throws it off his hand. A leather bag is brought, and he inserts his hand into it, then it is sealed with the Sultan's seal. When it is after three [days], unhusked rice is brought and it is said to him: 'Rub it.' If there is no trace on his hand, he has succeeded and there is no killing upon him. The one against whom the claim was made is fined a maund (mann) of gold which the Sultan seizes for himself. Sometimes they boil water in an iron or copper pot until no one can approach it, then an iron ring is thrown into it, and it is said: 'Insert your hand and take the ring.' I have seen one who inserted his hand and brought it out healthy. The claimant is also fined a maund of gold.

[Custom of the People of Serendib regarding the Death of their Kings]

If the King dies in the lands of Serendib [Sri Lanka], he is placed on a low carriage close to the ground, and hung at its rear lying on his back, the hair of his head dragging in the dust from the ground. A woman with a broom in her hand throws dust on his head and calls out: 'O people, this is your king; yesterday he owned you and his command was effective among you. He has come to what you see of leaving the world, and the Angel of Death has taken his soul. So do not be deceived by life after him.' And speech like this for three days. Then sandalwood (1), camphor, and saffron are prepared for him, and he is burned with it. Then his ashes are thrown into the wind (2). All of India burn their dead with fire.

[Customs of the People of India in Burning their Dead and their Worships]

Serendib (1) is the last of the islands and is of the lands of India. Perhaps the King is burned, so his wives enter the fire and burn with him, and if they wish, they do not do so. In the lands of India are those attributed to wandering (Siyahah) in forests and mountains; they rarely associate with people and sometimes eat herbs and forest fruits. He puts an iron ring on his penis so he does not approach women. Among them is the naked one, and among them is one who sets himself up to the sun facing it naked, except that upon him is something of leopard skins. I saw a man of them as I described, then I departed and returned after sixteen years, and saw him in that state. I marveled how his eye did not melt from the heat of the sun.

[Their Inheritance of Kingship and Crafts]

The people of the royal house in every kingdom are people of one house; kingship does not leave them, and they have heirs apparent. Likewise, the people of writing (scribes) and medicine are people of houses; that craft is not except among them. The kings of India do not submit to a single king, but rather each one is king of his lands. The Ballahara is the King of Kings in India. As for China, they do not have heirs apparent.

[Abstention of the Kings of India from Amusement and Wine]

The people of China are people of amusements. The people of India fault amusements and do not adopt them, nor do they drink wine nor eat vinegar because it is from wine. That is not religion but disdain. They say: 'Any king who drinks wine is not a king.' That is because around them are kings who fight them, so they say:

'How can one who is drunk manage the affair of his kingdom?' (1). Perhaps they fight over kingship, and that is rare. I have not seen anyone conquer anyone over his kingdom except a people following the lands of pepper. If a king conquers a kingdom, he appoints over it a man from the household of the conquered king, and he is under his authority; the people of that kingdom are not satisfied except with that.

[The People of China Eating the Flesh of their Kings]

As for the lands of China, perhaps the king who is under the authority of the Greatest King acts unjustly, so they slaughter him and eat him. Everyone killed by the sword, the Chinese eat his flesh. The people of India and China, if they want to marry, congratulate each other, then exchange gifts, then publicize the marriage with cymbals and drums. Their gift is of money according to ability. If a man among them brings a woman and she commits adultery, killing is upon her and upon the one who committed adultery with her in all the lands of India. If a man commits adultery with a woman forcing her, the man alone is killed. If he commits adultery with a woman with her consent, they are both killed.

[Their Judgment in the Penalty of Theft]

Theft (2) in all the lands of China and India, in little of it and much, is killing. As for India, if the thief steals a fils (penny) or more, a long piece of wood is taken, its end sharpened, then he is impaled upon it from his buttocks until it comes out of his throat.

The people of China sodomize boys who have been set up for that like the prostitutes of the idolaters (Al-Badadah) (1).

[Buildings of the People of China and India]

The walls of the people of China are wood. The building of the people of India is stone, gypsum, baked brick, and clay. Likewise, perhaps it was in China too. Neither China nor India are people of carpets. A man from China and India marries whatever he wishes of women. The food of India is rice, and the food of China is wheat and rice. The people of India do not eat wheat. Neither India nor China practice circumcision.

[Religion of the People of China and India]

The people of China worship idols, pray to them, and humble themselves before them. They have religious books.

[Miscellaneous Wonders]

The Indians lengthen their beards; perhaps the beard of one of them exceeds three cubits. They do not trim their mustaches. Most of the people of China have no beards by nature for most of them. The people of India, if one of them has a death, he shaves his head and beard. The Indians, if they imprison a man or detain him, prevent him from food and drink for seven days while they are detaining him. The people of China have judges who judge between them other than the governors, and likewise the people of India.

Leopards and wolves are in all the lands of China. As for lions, they are not in either of the two provinces. The highway robber is killed. The people of China and India claim that the idols (Al-Badadah) speak to them, but it is their worshippers who speak to them. China and India kill what they want to eat and do not slaughter it; they strike its skull until it dies. Neither India nor China wash themselves from major ritual impurity (Janabah). The people of China do not clean themselves after defecation except with paper. The Indians wash themselves every day before lunch then eat. The Indians do not approach women during menstruation and expel them from their homes out of disgust for them. The Chinese approach them during menstruation and do not expel them. The people of India use the toothstick (Siwak); one of them does not eat until he uses the toothstick and washes. The people of China do not do that. The lands of India are vaster than the lands of China and multiples of it, and the number of their kings is greater. The lands of China are more populated. Neither China nor India have palm trees, but they have other trees and fruits not with us. The Indians have no grapes, and it is scarce in China. Other fruits are abundant with them, and pomegranates are more in India. The people of China have no science; the origin of their religion is from India. They claim that the Indians established the idols for them, and that they are the people of religion. Both countries return to reincarnation (transmigration of souls) and differ in the branches of their religion (1). Medicine is in India, and philosophers. The people of China also have medicine, and most of their medicine is...

...cauterization. They have knowledge of astronomy, and that is more in India. I do not know anyone of the two groups who is Muslim or speaks Arabic. India has few horses, and they are more for China. China has no elephants, and they do not leave them in their lands considering them bad omens. The armies of the King of India are numerous and are not paid; rather, the King calls them to Jihad, so they go out spending from their own wealth; nothing of that is on the King. As for China, their giving is like the giving of the Arabs. The lands of China are more pleasant and beautiful. Most of India has no cities, while the people of China in every place have a great fortified city. The lands of China are healthier, with fewer diseases and better air; a blind or one-eyed person or one with a defect is hardly seen there, and this is frequent in the lands of India. The rivers of both countries are great, some greater than our rivers. Rains in both countries are frequent. In the lands of India are many deserts, while China is all populated. The people of China are more beautiful than the people of India, and more similar to the Arabs in clothing and beasts. In their appearance in their processions, they are similar to the Arabs; they wear tunics (Qaba') (1) and belts. The people of India wear two wraps (Futa) and adorn themselves with gold bracelets and gems, men and women. Behind the lands of China on the earth are the Taghazghuz (Toquz Oghuz) (2), and they are from the Turks,

and the Khaqan (1) of Tibet (2). This is adjacent to the lands of the Turks. As for what is adjacent to the sea, there are the islands of Al-Sila (Korea); they are white and send gifts to the ruler of China. They claim that if they did not gift him, the sky would not rain on them. None of our companions has reached it to recount about them. They have white falcons.

The First Book is Completed.
The poor [servant] Muhammad looked into this book in the year one thousand and eleven [1011 AH]. May Allah improve its outcome and what is after it. Amen. O Allah, forgive its scribe, his parents, and the Muslims.

The Second Book of the Reports of China and India
Abu Zayd al-Hasan al-Sirafi said: I looked into this book, meaning the First Book, which I was ordered to examine and record what I learned of the matter of the sea, its kings, and their conditions, and what I knew of their stories which did not enter into it. I found the date of the book to be in the year two hundred and thirty-seven. The matters of the sea at that time were stable due to the frequent coming and going of merchants to it from Iraq.

[The Author's Refutation of the Myth that the Dead Eat Food]

I found all that was recounted in the book to be on the path of truth and honesty, except what was mentioned therein of the food which the people of China present to their dead, and that if it is placed at night near the deceased, they wake up and it is not found, claiming that he eats it. This had reached us until one whom we trusted with his news arrived from their region, so we asked him about that and he denied it. He said: 'It is a claim with no basis, like the claim of the idolaters that they speak to them.' The matter of China specifically changed after this date, and incidents occurred in it for which the equipment (shipping) (1) to them was cut off, the country was ruined, its customs vanished, and its affair dispersed. I will explain what I learned of the reason for that, Allah willing:

The Reason for the Change of the Affair of China from what it was of Judgments and Justice,

and the cutting off of shipping to it from Siraf: A rebel rebelled among them not from the royal house known as Banshu (Huang Chao) (1). His beginning was villainy (2), bravado, carrying arms, causing corruption, and the gathering of fools to him until his power intensified, his numbers increased, and his greed became established. He targeted Khanfu [Guangzhou] among the cities of China, which is the city intended by Arab merchants. Between it and the sea is a journey of a few days, and it is on a great river and fresh water. Its people held out against him, so he besieged them for a long time, and that was in the year two hundred and sixty-four, until he conquered it. He put the sword to its people. Those knowledgeable about their affairs mentioned that he killed of the Muslims, Jews, Christians, and Magians, excluding who was killed of the people of China, one hundred and twenty thousand men who had settled in this city and become merchants in it. The number of these four communities was only known because of the levy on the people of China by their number. He cut down the mulberry trees and other trees that were in it. We mentioned the mulberry trees specifically because the people of China prepare its leaves for silkworms until the worm spins. So it became a cause for the cutting off of silk specifically from the lands of the Arabs. Then, after destroying Khanfu, he targeted city after city and destroyed it. The King of China was incapable against him until he approached the capital city, known as Khamdan [Xi'an] (3). The King fled...

...from him to the city of Bamdhu [Chengdu?] bordering the lands of Tibet and stayed there. The days of this rebel lasted, and his affair became great. His intent and aim were destroying cities and killing their people since he was not from a royal house nor one who hopes for the order to be consistent for him. He reached in that an extent by which the affair of China was corrupted to this time of ours. That remained the condition of this rebel until the King of China wrote to the King of the Taghazghuz of the lands of the Turks - and between them is neighborliness and marriage relations - and sent messengers to him asking him to remove this man from him. The King of the Taghazghuz sent a son of his to this rebel (1) with a large number and ample crowds, so he removed him after continuous wars and great battles. Some claimed he was killed, and others claimed he died. The King of China returned to his city known as Khamdan, which he [the rebel] had ruined for him, and in a state of weakness in himself, decrease in his wealth, and the perishing of his commanders, brave men, and capable ones. Along with that, a usurper prevailed over every region, withholding its wealth and holding on to what was in his hand of it. Necessity called the King of China, due to the shortness of his hand (lack of power), to accept pardon from them by [their] showing obedience and praying for him without hearing and obeying regarding wealth. The Kings used to have influence in it. So the lands of China became in the way the conditions of the Kisras (Persian Kings) went when Alexander killed Darius (2) the Great and the land of Persia was divided among the Kings of the Sects (Muluk al-Tawa'if). Some of them began to support others for domination without the permission of the King or his command. If the strong one among them knelt upon the weak, he conquered his lands, eradicated what was in it, and ate all its people. That is permissible for them in their law because they trade human flesh in their markets. Their hands extended with that to oppressing the merchants who intended [to visit] them.

When this happened among them, the appearance of injustice and aggression in the Nakhudas (shipmasters) (1) of the Arabs and the ship owners joined it. They obligated the merchants with what was not due upon them, overcame them regarding their wealth, and permitted what was not the custom of old in any of their actions. So Allah, may His mention be exalted, removed blessings from all of them, the sea withheld its side, and destruction occurred by the decree flowing from the Disposer, blessed be His name, among the captains (Rubbanah) (2) and guides (Adilla') in Siraf and Oman.

[Some of the Judgments of the People of China regarding Felonies]

A part of the sunan (laws/customs) of the people of China was mentioned in the book, and others did not mention it, which is: the path of the married man and married woman among them if they commit adultery is killing, and likewise the thief and the murderer. Their path in killing is that the hands of the one they want to kill are tied tightly, then his hands are thrown to his head until they are on his neck. Then his right leg is inserted into what passes through his right hand, and his left leg into what passes through his left hand. Both his feet become behind him, and he is contracted and remains like a ball; he has no stratagem for himself and does not need a holder to hold him. At that, his neck displaces from its joint, his vertebrae displace from their belly, his hips differ, some of him enters into others, his breath narrows, and he becomes in a state that if left as he is for a short time, he would perish. When he reaches [this state], he is beaten with a known piece of wood of theirs on his fatal spots with known blows that do not...

...exceed [the limit], so there is nothing short of his soul (death). Then he is given to one who eats him.

[Divan of Prostitutes]

Among them are women who do not want chastity (marriage) and desire adultery. The path of such is to attend the council of the Chief of Police and mention her abstinence from chastity and her desire to enter into the group of prostitutes, and ask to be treated according to the custom for her likes. It is their custom for whoever of the women wants that, to have her lineage, description, and place of residence written and recorded in the Divan of Prostitutes. A cord is placed on her neck with a copper ring stamped with the King's seal. A decree is given to her mentioning her entry into the group of prostitutes and that she owes the treasury such and such fils every year, and that whoever marries her is subject to killing. So she pays what she owes every year, and disapproval is removed from her. This class of women go out in the evenings wearing colorful clothes without covering, proceeding to those strangers who have come to those lands, people of debauchery and corruption, and the people of China. They stay with them and leave in the mornings. We praise Allah for what He has purified us from these trials (Fitnahs).

[Transactions of the People of China with Fulus (Copper Coins) and Trade]

As for their dealing with Fulus, the reason for it is their disapproval of those dealing with Dinars and Dirhams: That if a thief entered the house of a man of the Arabs dealing with Dinars and Dirhams, it would be possible for him to carry ten thousand Dinars and the like of silver on his neck, which would be the ruin of the owner of the money. But if a thief entered upon a man of them, he would not carry more than ten thousand fils, and that is only ten mithqals of gold.

[Fulus of the People of China]

These Fulus are made of copper and mixtures of other things kneaded with it. The Fils among them is the size of the Baghli Dirham (1). In its center is a wide hole to pass a cord through. The value of every thousand fils of it is a mithqal of gold. The cord strings a thousand fils of them, with a knot at the head of every hundred. If a buyer buys estates, goods, or vegetables and above, he pays from these Fulus according to the price. They are present in Siraf and have an inscription in their writing.

[Method of the People of China in Building their Houses]

As for fire in the lands of China and building and what was mentioned therein: The country is built as was said of wood and latticed bamboo like split reeds with us, plastered with clay and a treatment of theirs which they take from hemp seed (Shahdanaj) (128) (2), so it becomes whiter than milk. The walls are painted with it so they shine with a wondrous shine. Their houses have no thresholds (129) (3) because their possessions, treasures, and what their hands contain are in chests mounted on wheels with which they move. If a fire occurs, those chests with what is in them are pushed, and thresholds do not prevent them from quick passage.

[Servants of the Kings of China and their Eunuchs]

As for the matter of servants, it was mentioned briefly. They are only the governors of the land tax and the gates of wealth. Some of them are captured from the borders and castrated, and some are castrated by...

...their father from the people of China and gifted to the King seeking closeness to him. The affairs of the King in his private matters, his treasuries, and whoever heads to the city of Khanfu which Arab merchants intend, are the servants. Among their customs in the riding of these servants and the kings of other cities if they ride: Men precede them with wood resembling bells (Semantrons) which they strike. It is heard from afar, so no one of the subjects stands in any part of that road which the servant or king wants to pass through. Whoever is at the door of a house enters it and locks the door, until the passing of the servant or the King ruling over that city is done, and there is no one of the common people in his path, for intimidation and haughtiness, and lest the gaze of the common people at them increases, and lest the tongue of anyone extends to speak with them. (1)

[Skill of the People of China in the Silk Industry and Others]

The clothing of their servants and the notables of their commanders is luxurious silk, the like of which is not brought to the lands of the Arabs, due to their keeping it and their exaggeration in its prices. A man from the notable merchants, whose report is not doubted, mentioned: That he went to a eunuch whom the King had sent to the city of Khanfu to select what he needed of goods arriving from the lands of the Arabs. He saw on his chest a mole showing through from under silk clothes he was wearing. He estimated that he had doubled two garments of it. When he persisted in looking, the eunuch said to him: 'I see you staring at my chest, why is that?' The man said to him: 'I marveled at a mole showing through from under these clothes.' The eunuch laughed, then threw the sleeve of his shirt to the man and said to him: 'Count what is on me of them.' He found them to be five tunics one over another, and the mole showed through from under them. Silk of this description is raw, not bleached. What...

[Skill of the People of China in Precision Industries] (1)

The people of China are of the most skilled of Allah's creation in hand at engraving, manufacturing, and every work; no one from other nations precedes them in it. A man of them makes with his hand what he estimates others are incapable of, then heads with it to the King's gate seeking reward for the intricacy of what he invented. The King orders it to be set up at his gate from that time for a year. If no one finds a flaw in it, he rewards him and enters him into the group of his craftsmen. If a flaw is found in it, he discards it and does not reward him. A man of them depicted an ear of grain with a sparrow on it in a silk cloth; the viewer does not doubt that it is an ear of grain and that a sparrow is on it. It remained for a period. A hunchbacked man passed by it and faulted it. He was brought to the king of that city, and its maker attended. He asked the hunchback about the flaw. He said: 'It is known among all people that a sparrow does not land on an ear of grain without bending it, and this artist depicted the ear of grain standing straight with no bend, and fixed the sparrow upright on top of it, so he erred.' He was believed, and the King did not reward its maker with anything. Their intent in this and similar things is disciplining those who make these things to compel them to extreme caution and applying thought in what each of them makes with his hand.

[Story of Ibn Wahb al-Qurashi and what happened to him with the King of China] (2)

There was in Basra a man from Quraysh known as Ibn Wahb from the descendants of Habbar (3) ibn al-Aswad. He left it when it was ruined and ended up in Siraf. There was a ship wanting the lands of China, so his ambition moved him by the decree flowing upon...

He embarked on that ship to the lands of China, then his ambition led him to aim for its Great King. He traveled to Khamdan in about two months from the city known as Khanfu. He stayed at the King's gate for a long period, presenting petitions (Ruqa') and mentioning that he was from the family of the Prophethood of the Arabs. After this period, the King ordered him to be lodged in one of the residences and his needs to be fulfilled. The King wrote to the governor acting as deputy residing in Khanfu, ordering him to investigate and ask the merchants about what the man claimed of kinship to the Prophet of the Arabs, peace be upon him. The ruler of Khanfu wrote confirming his lineage, so he permitted him [audience] and gave him ample wealth with which he returned to Iraq. He was an understanding old man. He told us: When he reached him [the King], he asked him about the Arabs and how they removed the kingdom of the Persians. He said to him: By Allah, may His mention be exalted, and because of what the Persians were upon of worshipping fires and prostrating to the sun and moon instead of Allah. He said to him: The Arabs have conquered the most majestic of kingdoms, the most extensive in fertile lands, the most abundant in wealth, the most intelligent in men, and the furthest in fame. Then he said to him: What is the rank of the rest of the kings with you? He said: I have no knowledge of them. He said to the interpreter: Tell him we count the kings as five. The most extensive of them in kingdom is the one who rules Iraq, because he is in the middle of the world, and the kings surround him; we find his name with us to be the King of Kings. After him is this king of ours, and we find him with us to be the King of People, because no one of the kings is more politic than us, nor more controlling of his kingdom than our control of our kingdom, nor are any subjects more obedient to their kings than our subjects; so we are the Kings of People. After us is the King of Beasts, who is the King of the Turks adjacent to us. After them is the King of Elephants, who is the King of India; we find with us [he is] the King of Wisdom because its origin is from them. After him is the King of the Romans (Byzantines), and he is with us the King of Men, because there is no one on earth more perfect in physique among his men nor more beautiful in faces. These are the notables of kings, and the rest are below them.

Then he said to the interpreter: Tell him, do you know your Companion (the Prophet) if you saw him? Meaning the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. I said: How can I see him when he is with Allah, Mighty and Majestic? He said: I did not mean this; I only meant his image. He said: Yes. So he ordered a chest to be brought out and placed before him. He took a scroll from it and said to the interpreter: Show him his Companion. I saw in the scroll images of the Prophets, so I moved my lips in prayer upon them. He did not know that I recognized them. He said to the interpreter: Ask him about the moving of his lips. He asked me, and I said: I am praying upon the Prophets. He said: From where did you know them? I said: From what is depicted of their affair. This is Noah in the Ark, saved with those with him when Allah, may His mention be exalted, commanded the water and it flooded the whole earth with whoever was in it, and He saved him and those with him. He laughed and said: As for Noah, you have spoken the truth in naming him. As for the drowning of the whole earth, we do not know it; the Flood only took a piece of the earth and did not reach our land nor the land of India. Ibn Wahb said: I feared refuting him and establishing the argument because of my knowledge of his rejection of that. Then I said: This is Moses and his staff and the Children of Israel. He said: Yes, despite the smallness of the land he was in and the corruption of his people against him. I said: And this is Jesus on a donkey and the Disciples with him. He said: He was short in duration; his affair was only a little more than thirty months. He enumerated of the affair of the rest of the Prophets what we have limited ourselves to mentioning some of. He claimed that he saw above every image of a Prophet a long writing which he estimated contained the mention of their names, the locations of their countries, and the reasons for their prophecies. Then he said: I saw the image of the Prophet, peace be upon him, on a camel and his companions surrounding him on their camels, with Arab sandals on their feet and tooth-sticks (Siwak) tied at their waists. So I wept. He said to the interpreter: Ask him about his weeping. I said: This is our Prophet and our Master and my cousin, peace be upon him. He said:

You have spoken the truth. He and his people have possessed the most majestic of kingdoms, except that he did not see what he possessed, but those after him saw it. I saw images of Prophets of a large number; some of them pointing with their right hand, joining the thumb and index finger as if indicating the truth in their gesture; and some standing on their feet pointing with their fingers to the sky; and other things. The interpreter claimed they were from their prophets and the prophets of India. Then he asked me about the Caliphs, their attire, and many of the laws and their aspects to the extent of what I knew of them. Then he said: How old is the world according to you? I said: It is differed upon. Some say: six thousand years, some say less than that, and some say more than that but by a little. He laughed a great laugh, and his vizier also standing indicated his denial of that. He said: I do not reckon your Prophet said this. I slipped and said: Yes, he said that. I saw denial in his face. Then he said to the interpreter: Tell him to watch his words, for Kings are not spoken to except with verification. As for what you claimed that you differ in that, you only differed in the saying of your Prophet; and what the Prophets said should not be differed upon, but rather it is accepted. So beware of narrating this and its like. He mentioned many things that have escaped me due to the length of time. Then he said to me: Why did you turn away from a King who is closer to you than us in abode and lineage? I said: Because of what happened to Basra and my ending up in Siraf, and my seeing a ship departing to China, and what reached me of the majesty of the King of China and the abundance of good in him, so I loved to fall upon that region and witness it. I am returning from it to my country and the kingdom of my cousin, informing of what I witnessed of the majesty of this King and the vastness of these lands.
