I will speak with every goodness and praise with every beauty. That pleased him, and he ordered for me a splendid gift, and for me to be carried on post mules to the city of Khanfu. He wrote to its king to honor me and put me ahead of all who are...

...in his region of other kings, and to provide accommodation for me until the time of my departure. So I was in the most fertile and comfortable living until I left the lands of China.

[The City of Khamdan and the Seat of the King]

We asked him about the city of Khamdan where the King is, and its description. He mentioned the vastness of the city and the large number of its people, and that it is divided into two sections separated by a long wide street. The King, his vizier, his soldiers, the Chief Judge, the King's eunuchs, and all his retinue are in the right section of it and what follows the East. No one from the common people mixes with them, nor are there any markets in it. [It has] flowing rivers in their lanes, trees arranged upon them, and spacious houses. In the left section which follows the West: the subjects, merchants, provisions, and markets. When the day becomes bright, you see the stewards (1) of the King, his retinue, the slave-boys of his house, and the slave-boys of the commanders and their agents, riding and walking, entering the section where the markets and merchants are. They take their allowances and needs, then depart, and none of them returns to this section except on the second day (2). In this city is every pleasure, beautiful forest, and flowing rivers, except for palm trees, for they are non-existent.

[Connection of the Sea of China and India with the Sea of Sham (3)]

Among what happened in our time and was not known by those who preceded us, is that no one...

estimated that the sea on which is the Sea of China and India connects to the Sea of Sham (Mediterranean), nor did it arise in their minds until it was in this age of ours. It reached us that wood from the stitched Arab ships, which had broken with their people, was found in the Sea of Rome (Mediterranean). The waves cut it up and the winds drove it with the waves of the sea, casting it into the Sea of the Khazars (Caspian/Black Sea?), then it flowed into the Gulf of Rome (Constantinople/Bosporus?) and passed from it to the Sea of Rome and Sham. This indicated that the ocean circles the lands of China and Silla (1) and the back of the lands of the Turks and Khazars, then pours into the Gulf and leads to the lands of Sham. That is because stitched wood (2) is only for the ships of Siraf specifically, while the ships of Sham and Rome are nailed, not stitched. It also reached us that Ambergris was found in the Sea of Sham, and this is among the strange things and what was not known in ancient times. It is not possible, if what was said is true, that the Ambergris fell into the Sea of Sham except from the Sea of Aden and Qulzum (Red Sea), which is the sea connected to the seas where Ambergris is found, because Allah, may His mention be exalted, has placed a barrier between the two seas. Rather, if it is true, it is from what the Sea of India casts to the rest of the seas one after another until it leads with it to the Sea of Sham.

[Mention of the City of Zabaj]

Then we begin by mentioning the city of Zabaj (1) as it is opposite the lands of China. Between them is a month's journey by sea, and less than that if the winds assist. Its king is known as the Maharaja (2). It is said: Its area (3) is nine hundred parasangs. This king is king over many islands; the extent of the distance of his kingdom is a thousand parasangs and more. In his kingdom is an island known as Sarirah (4), its area as they mention is four hundred parasangs. And an island also known as Rami (5), its area is eight hundred parasangs; in it are plantations of Brazilwood, Camphor, and others. In his kingdom is the island of Kalah, which is the midpoint between the lands of China and the land of the Arabs; its area as they mention is eighty parasangs. In Kalah is the gathering of goods from Aloeswood, Camphor, Sandalwood, Ivory, Tin (Rasas Qal'i), Ebony, Brazilwood, and all spices, and other things whose explanation would be vast and long. Shipping from Oman at this time to it, and from it to Oman, is happening. The command of the Maharaja is effective in these islands. His island where he is, is in...

utmost fertility and its population is organized. Someone whose word is trusted mentioned: That when the roosters crow at dawn for the times as they crow with us, they answer each other for up to a hundred parasangs and more, answering one another due to the connection of villages and their regularity. There are no deserts in it, nor ruins. The traveler in their lands, if he travels and rides a mount, travels if he wishes, and if he tires and the mount is weary, he stops where he wishes.

[The Rule of the Maharaja in Storing Gold and Distributing It]

Among the wonders that reached us from the stories of this island known as Zabaj is that a king of their kings in ancient times, who is the Maharaja - and his palace is on a Thalaj [estuary/inlet] taking from the sea. The meaning of Thalaj is a valley like the Tigris of the City of Peace (1) and Basra; the sea water overcomes it at high tide and the fresh water recedes from it at low tide. From it is a small pond adjacent to the King's palace. When it is the morning (2) of every day, the King's steward enters carrying a brick he has cast from gold containing a Mana (3) [weight], the amount of which is hidden from me. He throws it before the King into that pond. When it is high tide, the water covers it and what was gathered with it of its likes, submerging it. When it is low tide, the water recedes from it, revealing it, so it shines in the sun. The King looks upon it when sitting in the council overlooking it. That remains the case, a brick of gold is thrown every day into that pond as long as...

that King lives for a time; nothing is touched of it. When the King dies, the successor after him takes it all out and leaves nothing of it. It is counted, then melted and distributed among the people of the royal house, their men, women, children, commanders, and servants, according to their ranks and customs for each class of them. What remains after that is distributed among the poor and weak. Then the number of gold bricks and their weight is recorded, and it is said that So-and-so reigned for such-and-such years, and left of gold bricks in the Pond of Kings such-and-such bricks, and that they were distributed after his death among the people of his kingdom. Pride among them is for he whose days of reign extended and the number of gold bricks in his legacy increased.

[The King of Qumar]

Among their news in the ancient past is that a king of the kings of Qumar (1) - which is the land from which Qumari Aloeswood (2) is imported, and it is not an island but rather on what follows the land of the Arabs; there is no kingdom with a greater population than the people of Qumar. They are travelers. All of them forbid adultery and all wines, so there is nothing of it in their lands and kingdom. It is opposite the kingdom of the Maharaja and the island known as Zabaj. Between them is a distance of ten days to twenty days across the sea if the wind is moderate.

[Story of the King of Qumar, His Vizier, and His Story with the King of Zabaj]

It was said that this King assumed kingship over Qumar in ancient days, and he was a hasty youth. He sat one day in his palace overlooking a valley flowing with fresh water like the (Tigris) of Iraq. Between his palace and the sea is a day's journey. His vizier was before him. He said to his vizier - and the mention of the kingdom of the Maharaja, its majesty, its large population, and the islands under his hand had occurred - 'There is a desire in my soul I would love to attain.' The vizier - who was sincere and knew of his haste - said: 'What is it, O King?' He said: 'I would love to see the head of the Maharaja, King of Zabaj, in a basin before me.' The vizier knew that envy had stirred this thought in his soul. He said: 'O King, I would not like the King to speak to himself of the likes of this, since there has not occurred between us and these people, neither in deed nor in speech, any wrong (1), nor have we seen evil from them. They are in a distant island not neighboring us in our land, nor coveting our kingdom. It is not appropriate for anyone to know of this speech, nor for the King to repeat a saying in it.' He became angry and did not listen to the sincere adviser. He broadcast that to his commanders and those present of his notable companions. Tongues transmitted it until it spread and reached the Maharaja. He was prudent (2), active, and seasoned, having reached a middle age. He called for his vizier and informed him of what reached him. He said to him: 'It is not right, from what has spread of the affair of this ignorant one and his wishing what he wished due to his young age and delusion, and the spread of that from his speech, that we refrain from him. For that weakens the King's strength, diminishes him, and lowers him.' He ordered him to conceal what passed between them, and to prepare for him a thousand ships...

...of medium ships with their equipment, and to assign to each ship from the weaponry and brave men what it can carry. He pretended that he wanted to tour the islands in his kingdom. He wrote to the kings in these islands who were under his obedience, informing them of his intent to visit them and tour their islands, until that spread. The king of every island prepared what was suitable for the Maharaja. When his affair was set and organized, he boarded the ships and crossed with them and the army to the kingdom of Qumar. He and his companions were people of constant use of the tooth-stick (Siwak); a man of them does that times a day, and each one's Siwak is with him, not leaving him, or with his slave-boy. The King of Qumar did not sense him until he attacked the valley leading to the palace of the King of Qumar. He landed his men and they surrounded him by surprise. He seized him and took possession of his palace. The people of the kingdom fled before him. He ordered a proclamation of safety. He sat on the throne on which the King of Qumar used to sit. He had taken him prisoner, so he brought him and brought his vizier. He said to the King of Qumar: 'What prompted you to wish for what is not in your power, nor do you have fortune in it if you attained it, nor did a cause necessitate facilitating the way to it?' He did not return an answer. Then the Maharaja said to him: 'Had you wished, from what you wished of looking at my head in a basin before you, for the permissibility of my land and its ownership or corruption in any of it, I would have applied all that to you. But you wished for a specific thing, so I am doing it to you and returning to my country without extending a hand to anything of your country, large or small, so it may be a lesson for those after you, that everyone should not exceed his measure and what is allotted to him, and that he should seize safety from his confusion.' Then he struck off his neck. Then he turned to his vizier and said to him: 'May you be rewarded well for a vizier. It has been proven to me that you advised your master with an opinion if only he had accepted from you. So look for who...

...is suitable for kingship after this ignorant one and install him in his place.' He departed immediately returning to his country without him or any of his companions extending a hand to anything from the land of Qumar. When he returned to his kingdom, he sat on his throne and looked over his pond. He placed the basin before him with the head of the King of Qumar in it. He summoned the notables of his kingdom and told them his news and the reason that led him to what he undertook. The people of his kingdom prayed for him and rewarded him with good. Then he ordered the head to be washed and perfumed, placed it in a container, and returned it to the King who took charge in the land of Qumar after the killed King. He wrote to him: 'What led me to what we did to your master was his transgression against us, and our disciplining of his likes. We have achieved from him what he wanted for us. We saw fit to return the head to you as we have no benefit in keeping it, nor pride in what we gained from him.' The news reached the kings of India and China, so the Maharaja became great in their eyes. The kings of Qumar after that, whenever they woke up, stood and turned their faces towards the land of Zabaj, prostrated, and bowed to the earth for the Maharaja in veneration. The rest of the kings of India and China believe in reincarnation and profess it. Someone whose report is trusted mentioned that a king of theirs had smallpox (1). When he recovered from smallpox, he looked in the mirror and found his face ugly. He saw a son of his brother and said to him: 'The likes of me does not stay in this body with its change; it is only a vessel for the spirit. Whenever it leaves it, it returns in another. So take charge of the kingdom, for I am separating between my body and my spirit until I descend into another body.' Then he called for a dagger of his...

...sharp and cutting. He ordered it, and his head was severed, then burned.

Return to the News of China and Mention of Some of Their Affairs

The people of China, in the intense inspection of their affair in their ancient days and before its change in this time, were in a state the like of which has not been heard.

[Story of the Khurasani Merchant with the King's Eunuch]

A man from the people of Khorasan (1) arrived in Iraq, bought many goods, and went out to the lands of China. He had stinginess and severe miserliness. A dispute occurred between him and a eunuch of the King whom he had sent to Khanfu - which is the city intended by Arab merchants - to take what he needed of what arrives in ships. This eunuch was among the most majestic servants of the King, and to him belonged his treasuries and wealth. The dispute was over ivory goods and others; he refused to sell them until the matter became choked between them. The eunuch carried himself to snatch the best of goods that were with him and disdained his affair. He [the merchant] departed in secret until he reached Khamdan, which is the city of the Great King, in a period of two months and more. He went out to the chain that I described in the book. The path of one who moves it for the Great King is to be removed to a distance of ten days' journey by way of exile, and ordered to be imprisoned there for two months. Then the king of that region brings him out and says: 'You have exposed yourself to what (2) contains your ruin and the shedding of your blood if you are lying. Since the King has brought near to you and your likes, from his viziers and kings, those with whom justice is not lacking...

...for you, know that if you reach the King and what you complained of is not something for the likes of which access to him is obligatory, there is nothing short of your blood (death), so that everyone who intends the like of it does not dare to do what you did. So withdraw your move and go about your business.' If he withdraws, he beats him fifty strokes of wood and exiles him to the lands from which he came. If he persists in his grievance, he reaches [the King]. That was done with the Khurasani. He persisted in his grievance and sought access. He was sent and reached the King. The interpreter asked him about his affair. He informed him of what happened to him from the servant and his snatching from his hand what he snatched. The matter concerning it had spread in Khanfu and circulated. The King ordered the imprisonment of the Khurasani and the provision for his needs in food and drink. He instructed his vizier to write to the governors in Khanfu to investigate what the Khurasani claimed, uncover it, and tell the truth about it. He ordered the Commander of the Right, the Left, and the Commander of the Center the same. Upon these three, after the vizier, revolves the matter of his armies, and he trusts them with himself. If he rides with them in war or otherwise, each of them is in his rank. Each one of them wrote, having uncovered the matter, with what stood as proof of the validity of the Khurasani's claim. The reports reached the King successively from every side. He summoned the eunuch. When he arrived, he seized his wealth and stripped his treasuries from his hand. He said to him: 'Your right was death when you exposed me to a man who traveled from Khorasan - and it is on the border of my kingdom - and went to the lands of the Arabs, and from there to the kingdoms of India, then to my country seeking profit. You wanted him to return passing through these kingdoms and those in them saying: I was wronged in the lands of China and my wealth was usurped. But I refrain from your blood due to your old sanctity, and I appoint you to the management of the dead since you were incapable of managing the living.' He ordered him and placed him in the cemeteries...

...of the Kings to guard them and attend to them.

[Mention of Who Assumes the Judiciary and Their Testing of His Affair]

Among the wonders of their management in ancient days, not this time, is the matter of judgments and their majesty in their chests, and their choosing for them one whose knowledge of their laws, truthfulness of tongue, upholding of right in all his states, and avoidance of leniency towards the high-ranking so that right falls in its place, doubt does not trouble their hearts. He must be chaste regarding the wealth of the weak and what passes through his hand. If they decide to invest a Chief Judge, they send him before his investiture to all the towns which are the pillars of their lands, so he stays in every town for a month or two months searching into the affair of its people, their news, and their customs. He learns whose word among them must be accepted with a knowledge that dispenses with asking. When he has traveled these metropolises, and no majestic town remains in the kingdom but that he has trodden it, he travels to the Abode of the Kingdom. He is appointed the Judiciary of Judges and entrusted with their selection, so he governs them. With his knowledge of the whole kingdom and who should be invested in every town from its people or others, he knows who suffices with his knowledge without referring to one who might lean in it or speak untruthfully in what he is asked about. It is not possible for any of his judges to write to him with something he knows the contrary of, or to divert him from his direction. The Chief Judge has a crier every day calling (1) at his door saying: 'Is there anyone with a grievance against the King concealed from the eyes of his subjects, or against any of his retinue, his commanders, and the rest of his subjects? For I deputize in all that for him due to what he has extended my hand in and invested me with.' He says that three times. Because the King, in their belief, is that the King does not leave his position until letters are executed from...

...the divans of kings with explicit injustice, and that he neglects the matter of judgment and judges. Whenever he guards against these two matters, and letters are not executed from the divans except with justice, and judgment is not administered except by one who upholds the truth, the kingdom is organized. As for Khorasan and its bordering the lands of China, what is between it and Sogdia is a two-month journey, except that it is in an impregnable desert and continuous sands with no water in them, no valleys, and no habitation near them. This is the reason preventing the attack of the people of Khorasan on their country. As for what is of China following the setting of the sun, which is the place known as Madhu [?], it is on the borders of Tibet and wars between them are continuous. We have seen among those who entered China one who mentioned: That he saw a man carrying musk in a skin on his back, who arrived from Samarkand on foot, crossing town by town of the cities of China until he reached Khanfu, which is the gathering place of merchants intending from Siraf.

[Mention of Musk Extraction]

That is because the land containing the Chinese musk deer and Tibet is one land, no difference between them. The people of China attract what is near them of the deer, and the people of Tibet what is near them. Tibetan musk is superior to Chinese in two conditions: One of them is that the musk deer in the border of Tibet grazes on spikenard (Sunbul al-Tib), while in what follows the land of China its grazing is the rest of the herbs.

The other condition: The people of Tibet leave the pods in their state, while the people of China adulterate what falls to them of it. Also their traveling by sea and the harm that befalls them. If the people of China leave the musk in its pods and deposit it in jars, secure it, and it arrives in the land of the Arabs, it is like the Tibetan in its quality. The best of all musk is what the deer rubs on the stones of the mountains, as it is a substance that forms in its navel and fresh blood gathers like the gathering of blood in what occurs of boils. When it matures, it itches and annoys it, so it resorts to stones to rub it until it bursts and what is in it flows. When it exits from it, it dries and heals, and the substance returns to gather in it as before. Tibet has men who go out seeking this; they have knowledge of it. If they find it, they pick it up, gather it, deposit it in pods, and carry it to their kings. It is the ultimate musk since it matured in its pods on its animal. It has superiority over other musk like the superiority of what matures of fruits on a tree over the rest of what is plucked from it before its maturation. Other than this musk is only hunted by set traps or arrows. Perhaps the pods are cut from the deer before the maturation of the musk in them. Even if it is cut from its deer, it is foul-smelling for a period of time until (1) it dries over long days. Whenever it dries, it transforms until it becomes musk. The musk deer is like the rest of the deer with us in stature and color, thinness of legs, separation of hooves, erection of horns and their curvature. It has two thin white fangs in the jaws standing in the face of the deer; the length of each one is the amount of a span (Fitr), and less, in the form of the tusk of...

...the elephant. This is the difference between it and the rest of the deer. The correspondence of the kings of China to the kings of their metropolises and their eunuchs is on post mules with docked tails in the manner of post mules with us on known routes. The people of China, whatever we described of their affair, urinate standing up, and likewise the rest of their subjects from the people of their lands. As for the kings, commanders, and notables, they have painted wooden tubes, the length of each piece of wood is a cubit. At the two ends are two holes; the upper one widens for the glans. He stands on his leg when he wants to urinate, distances it from himself, and urinates in it. They claim that this is healthier for their bodies, and that the rest of what afflicts of bladder pain and urine stone formation (1) therein is only from sitting to urinate, and that the bladder does not clear what is in it except with standing for that. The reason for their leaving the hair on their heads, meaning the men, is their abstention from rounding the head of the newborn and shaping it as the Arabs use. Their saying is that this is what removes the brain from the state it was created upon, and that it corrupts the known sense. So their heads are irregular, covered by hair and concealed. As for marriages in the lands of China, they are peoples and tribes like the tribes of the Children of Israel (2) and the Arabs and their clans; they know that among themselves. None of them marries a relative or one of kin. They exceed that so that the tribe does not marry within its tribe. The example of that is that Banu Tamim do not marry into Tamim, and Rabi'ah does not...

...marry into Rabi'ah. Rather, Rabi'ah marries into Mudar, and Mudar into Rabi'ah. They claim that this is more productive for offspring.

Some News of India
In the kingdom of Balhara and others of the kings of India are those who burn themselves with fire. That is because of their belief in reincarnation, its establishment in their hearts, and the removal of doubt in it from them.

[Mention of the People of India Burning Themselves]

Among their kings is one who, when he sits for kingship, rice is cooked for him then placed before him on banana leaves. Three hundred or four hundred of his companions volunteer by their own choice, not by compulsion from the King for them. The King gives them from that rice after he eats from it. Man after man of them approaches and takes a small amount from it and eats it. It becomes binding on everyone who ate from this rice, if the King dies or is killed, to burn themselves with fire to the last of them on the day he died; they do not delay from it so that no eye or trace of them remains. If a man resolves to burn himself, he goes to the King's gate and asks permission. Then he goes around the markets while fire has been kindled for him in much large firewood, with men tending to its ignition until it becomes like agate in heat and inflammation. Then he runs, with cymbals before him, circling in the markets, surrounded by his family and relatives. Some of them place on their head a wreath of basil filled with embers, and pour Sandarac (1) on it. He is with the fire...

...like naphtha. He walks while the crown of his head burns and the smells of the flesh of his head waft. He does not falter in his walk, nor does anxiety appear from him, until he comes to the fire and throws himself into it, becoming ashes. Some of those who attended a man of them wanting to enter the fire mentioned: That when he looked over it, he took a dagger and placed it on the top of his heart, then split it with his hand to his pubis. Then he inserted his left hand and grasped his liver, pulling from it what he could while speaking. Then he cut a piece of it with the dagger and gave it to his brother, in disdain of death and patience over pain. Then he threw himself into the fire to the curse of Allah. (1) This recounting man claimed: That in the mountains of this region are a people of India whose path is the path of the Kanifiyya (2) and Jalidiyya (3) with us in seeking falsehood and ignorance. Between them and the people of the coast is partisanship. A man from the people of the coast ceases not to enter the mountain and challenge one to endure with him in mutilating (4) himself, and likewise the people of the mountain to the people of the coast. A man from the people of the mountains went to the people of the coast for the like of that. People gathered to him, between onlookers and partisans. He demanded of the people of partisanship to do like what he does; if they are incapable of it, they acknowledge defeat. He sat at the head of a bamboo grove and ordered them to pull a stalk from those bamboos. Its path is the path of reeds in...

...its wrapping, and its base is like a jar (1) and thicker. If the head of the stalk is pulled down, it responds until it approaches the ground. If released, it returns to its state. He pulled the head of a thick stalk until it came near him, then he tied his braids to it firmly. Then he took the dagger, which was like fire in its speed, and said to them: 'I am cutting my head with it. If it separates from my body, release it [the bamboo] immediately. I will laugh when the stalk returns with my head to its place, and you will hear a slight chuckle.' The people of the coast were incapable of doing the like of that. We have been told this by one whom we do not suspect, and it is known today as these lands of India are close to the lands of the Arabs, and their news is connected to them at all times. It is of their affair that if age takes their men and women and their senses weaken, the one who reaches this state among them demands his family to throw him into the fire or drown him in water, out of confidence from them in the return. The path of their dead is burning. In the island of Serendib, where the Mountain of Gems and the pearl diving places and other things are, an Indian man dares to enter the market with the Jarbi, which is a dagger of theirs of wondrous make, sharpened. He strikes with his hand the most majestic (2) merchant he can, grabs him by his collar, brandishes the dagger over him, and takes him out of the town in a gathering of people who can devise no stratagem for him. That is because if it is desired to snatch it from him, he kills the merchant and kills himself. If he exits the town, he demands ransom, and someone follows the merchant to ransom him with much money. That continued with them for a period of...

time passed until a king ruled them who ordered that whoever did that [attacked merchants] from the Indians be taken in whatever state he was. So that was done; the Indian merchant was killed, and he killed himself. This happened to a group of them, and lives of Indians and Arabs were lost in it. When the severity occurred, that ceased, and the merchants became safe for themselves. The red, green, and yellow gems are extracted from the mountain of Sarandib [Sri Lanka], which is an island. Most of what appears to them is at the time of the tides «1»; the water rolls it onto them from caves, grottos, and water streams where they have guards for the king. Sometimes they also excavate it just as mines are excavated, so the gem comes out attached to the stones and is broken off from it. [Mention of the religions of the people of the Island of Sarandib and their laws] The king of this island has a law and sheikhs who have assemblies like the assemblies of our hadith scholars. The Indians gather to them, and they write down from them the biographies of their prophets and the sunnahs of their laws. In it is a great idol of pure gold; the sailors exaggerate the amount of its weight, and temples upon which great wealth has been spent. In this island is a large gathering of Jews and of other sects, and in it also are Thanawiyyah (Dualists) «2», and the king permits each group of them to practice their religion. Adjacent to this island are wide aghbab (inlets/bays)—and the meaning of ghubb is a great valley if it is excessive in its length and width and its mouth is into the sea. Those passing through this ghubb, known as the Ghubb of Sarandib, travel for two months and more in...

thickets, meadows, and temperate air. At the mouth of this Ghubb is the sea known as Harkand [Bay of Bengal]. It is a place of nazzah (pure/recreational spot?); a sheep there costs half a dirham. A group of men drink a drink cooked from bee honey with fresh grain of Dhadhi «1» for the like of that amount. Most of their activities are gambling with roosters (cockfighting) and backgammon (Nard). The roosters among them have huge bodies and abundant spurs «2»; they use small, sharp daggers for them which are tied to their spurs, then they are released. Their gambling is for gold, silver, lands, plants, and other things, so the winning rooster wins a sum of gold. Likewise, their playing with backgammon is always for high stakes, so that the weak among them and those with no money, from those who go seeking vanity and chivalry (futuwa), might gamble with his fingertips. He plays, and by his side is something in which walnut oil or sesame oil has been put—since olive oil is nonexistent among them—and under it is a fire heating it. Between them is a small, sharpened axe. If one of them defeats his companion, he places his hand on a stone, and the gambler strikes the fingertip of the defeated with the axe, severing it. The defeated places his hand in the oil while it is at the height of heat to cauterize it. That does not stop him from returning to play; so perhaps they part ways having lost all their fingertips. Some of them take a wick, soak it in oil, then place it on a limb of their body and light a fire in it so it burns, and the smell of flesh wafts while he plays backgammon, showing no anxiety.

Corruption (promiscuity) in this place is widespread among women and men, not prohibited, so that a sea merchant might invite the daughter of their king, and she comes to him in their thickets with the knowledge of her father. The sheikhs of the people of Siraf [Bandar Siraf, Iran] used to forbid sending merchandise to this region, especially the young men. Regarding the matter of 'Al-Yasarrah' which occurs in the lands of India—and its interpretation is 'The Rain' (Monsoon)—it lasts upon them in the summer for three months consecutively, night and day; the sky «1» does not withhold from them at all. They prepare their provisions before that. When the Yasarrah comes, they stay in their houses because they are made of wood with swept roofs shaded by grasses of theirs. No one of them appears except for an important matter, although the craftsmen work on their crafts in these places during this period. Perhaps the bottoms of their feet rot during this time. By this Yasarrah is their livelihood; if it did not happen, they would perish because their agriculture is rice—they know nothing else and have no sustenance other than it. It (the rice) is during this time in 'Haramat' «2» of theirs, cast down, needing no watering or labor. The meaning of Haramat is rice nurseries among them. When the sky clears from them, the rice reaches the limit in yield and abundance. It does not rain on them in winter. [Mention of the Ascetics of India, its Poets, and Philosophers] India has worshippers and people of knowledge known as Brahmins, poets who visit kings, astrologers, philosophers, soothsayers, and people who interpret the flight of crows and others. In it are sorcerers and people who manifest illusions and innovate in them, and that...

is in Qinnawj [Kannauj, India] «1» especially, and it is a great land in the Kingdom of Al-Jurz. [Mention of the Bikarjiyeen] In India, there are a people known as the Bikarjiyeen (Bhikshus/Yogis?), naked; their hair has covered their bodies and private parts, and their fingernails are long like spears because they are not cut, only what breaks off from them. They are on a path of wandering. Around the neck of every man of them is a string with a skull from the skulls of humans. If hunger becomes severe for him, he stands at the door of some Indians, and they hasten to him with cooked rice, rejoicing in him. He eats in that skull, and when he is satisfied, he departs and does not return to ask for food except at the time of his need. [Mention of the Budd] India has varieties of laws by which they draw near, as they claimed «2», to their Creator—exalted is Allah and glorious above what the oppressors say by a great height. Among them: A man builds a khan (inn) on their roads for travelers and installs a grocer in it from whom passersby buy their needs. He installs in the khan a promiscuous woman from the women of India, paying her so that passersby may obtain her, and that is considered by them as something they are rewarded for. In India, there are whores known as the Whores of the Budd (Idol). The reason for this is that when a woman makes a vow, if a beautiful girl is born to her, she brings her to the Budd—which is the idol they worship—and dedicates her to it. Then she takes a house for her in the market, hangs a curtain on it, and seats her on a chair so that the people of India and others from...

other religions who are permissive in their religion pass by her. She makes herself available for a known wage, and whenever she collects something from that, she hands it to the custodians of the idol to be spent on the maintenance of the temple. We praise Allah, Mighty and Majestic, for what He chose for us and for purifying us from the sins of those who disbelieve in Him. [Mention of the Idol of Multan] As for the idol known as Al-Multan [Multan, Pakistan], which is near Al-Mansurah, it is sought from a journey of many months. A man among them carries Indian Qamaruni Oud (aloeswood)—and Qamarun «1» [Kamrup/Assam or Khmer] is a land where fine aloeswood is found—until he brings it to this idol and gives it to the custodians for the incense of the idol. Among this aloeswood is that of which a Mann is worth two hundred dinars. Sometimes it is sealed, and the seal leaves an impression in it due to its softness «2». The merchants buy it from these custodians. [Mention of the Coconut and what is made from it] In India, there are worshippers in their laws who go to islands that appear in the sea, plant coconuts in them, and dig for water in them for reward and so that ships may pass by them and obtain [supplies] from them. In Oman, there are those who go to these islands containing coconuts with carpentry tools and other things. They cut from the coconut wood what they want, and when...

it dries, they cut it into planks. They spin from the coconut fiber what they use to sew that wood together, making a vessel from it. They carve masts «1» from it, weave sails from its leaves, and make ropes (Kharrabat) «2», which are the cables (Qulus) «3» for us, from its fiber. When they finish all of it, the ships are laden with coconuts and taken to Oman, where they are sold. Its blessing and benefit are great since everything made from it does not require anything else. [Mention of the Land of the Zanj] The land of the Zanj [East Africa] is vast. Everything that grows in it of durra (sorghum)—which is their staple food—sugar cane, and other trees is black among them. They have kings who raid one another. With their kings are men known as the 'Mukhazzamun' (Nose-pierced); their noses have been pierced and rings placed in them, and chains attached to the rings. When there is war, they advance, and a man holds the end of each chain, pulling it and preventing him from advancing until the ambassadors mediate between them. If peace occurs, [fine], otherwise those chains are tied around their necks and they are left to the war; no standing remains for him, and one of them does not leave his post unless he is killed. The Arabs have a great awe in their hearts; if they see a man from them, they prostrate to him and say: 'This is from a kingdom where the date palm tree grows,' due to the majesty of dates among them and in their hearts.

[Mention of their Orators] They have sermons, and there is no one among the nations like their orators in their tongues. Among them is one who worships by covering himself with a leopard skin or a monkey skin, taking a staff in his hand, and coming towards them. A crowd of them gathers to him, and he stands on his feet from day until night preaching to them, reminding them of Allah, Exalted is His mention, and describing to them the affairs of those of them who perished. From them, Zanj leopards are exported; they have redness and whiteness and are large and wide. [Mention of the Island of Socotra] In the sea is an island known as Socotra [Socotra, Yemen] «1». In it are the growing places of Socotran Aloe. Its location is near the land of the Zanj and the land of the Arabs. Most of its inhabitants are Christians. The reason for that is that when Alexander conquered the kingdom of Persia, his teacher Aristotle used to correspond with him, informing him of the lands he encountered. He wrote to him emphasizing the search for an island in the sea known as Socotra, and that in it are the growing places of Aloe, which is the greatest medicine without which purgatives (Iyarijat) «2» are not complete, and that the correct thing is to expel whoever is on this island and settle a group of Greeks in it to guard it so that Aloe may be transported from it to Syria, Rome, and Egypt. So Alexander sent and expelled its inhabitants from it and settled a gathering of Greeks in it. He commanded the Kings of the Sects (Muluk al-Tawa'if)—since...

they were, at his killing of Darius the Great, obedient to his hand—to preserve them. So they remained in protection until Allah sent Jesus, peace be upon him. His matter reached those Greeks on these islands, so they entered into the entirety of what the Romans entered into of Christianity. Their remnants are there to this time along with others who inhabited it, and it was not mentioned in this book. [Mention of Al-Shehr and the Land of the Arabs] —Meaning the first book—what is on the right of the sea upon the exit of ships from Oman and the land of the Arabs and their traversing the Great Sea. He only explained in it what was accessible of it since it contained the Sea of India and China, and in it was the destination of the one on whose behalf that book was written. In this sea, which is on the right of India going out from Oman, are the lands of Al-Shehr [Ash Shihr, Yemen], which are the growing places of Frankincense «1», and a land of the lands of Ad, Himyar, Jurhum, and the Tubba's. They have ancient Adite tongues in Arabic which most Arabs do not know. They have no villages, and they are in squalor and straitened living until their land ends at the land of Aden, the coasts of Yemen, and to Jeddah. And from Jeddah to Al-Jar [near Yanbu, Saudi Arabia] to the coast of Syria, then it leads to Al-Qulzum [Suez, Egypt] and the sea ends there. It is where Allah, Exalted is His mention, says: 'And He made between the two seas a barrier.' Then the sea turns from Al-Qulzum to the land of the Berbers, then connects to the western side facing the land of Yemen until it passes the land of Abyssinia, from which Berber leopard skins are imported; they are the best skins...

and the purest. And Zayla [Zeila, Somalia], in which are ambergris and Dhabl «1», which is turtle shells. [Mention of the Sea of Al-Qulzum] When the ships of the people of Siraf arrive in this sea which is on the right of the Sea of India and come to Jeddah, they stay there, and the goods in them that are carried to Egypt are transferred to the ships of Al-Qulzum [Red Sea ships]. That is because it is not possible for the ships of the Sirafis to traverse that sea due to its difficulty and the abundance of mountains (reefs) growing in it. There are no kings on any of its coasts and no habitation. If a ship traverses it, it needs to seek a place to shelter in every night for fear of its mountains; so it travels by day and stays by night. It is a dark sea with foul smells; there is no good in its belly or its back. It is not like the Sea of India and China, in whose belly are pearls and ambergris, in its mountains are gems and gold mines, in the mouths of its beasts is ivory, and in its vegetation places are ebony, brazilwood, bamboo, aloeswood trees, camphor, nutmeg, cloves, sandalwood, and all good, fragrant spices «2». Its birds are parrots (fafagha), peacocks, and the creeping things of its earth are civet (civet cats), musk gazelles, and what no one can count due to the abundance of its goodness. [Mention of what the Sea of Al-Qulzum casts of Ambergris] As for ambergris and what falls of it to the coasts of this sea, it is something the waves cast to it, and its origin is from the Sea of India, although its source is not known, except that the best of it is what falls to Barbara [Berbera, Somalia], the borders of the land of the Zanj, Al-Shehr, and what is adjacent to it, which is the round blue [ambergris].

The people of these regions have trained camels (nujub) which they ride on moonlit nights, traveling with them on their coasts. They have been trained and know how to seek ambergris on the coast. If the camel sees it, it kneels with its owner, and he takes it. Some of it is found floating on the sea and weighs a great weight. Perhaps it is like the shape of a bull or smaller. If the whale (Hut) known as Al-Bal «1» sees it, it swallows it. When it settles in its belly, it kills it, and the whale floats on the water. There are people who watch for it in boats who know the times when these whales that have swallowed ambergris are found. If they see any of them, they drag it to the land with iron hooks having stout ropes that snag into the back of the whale. They cut it open and extract the ambergris from it. What was next to the belly of the whale is the 'Mand' which has a fishy smell (sahuka); its thickness is found with the perfumers in the City of Peace [Baghdad] and Basra «2». What the fishy smell of the whale did not reach is very pure. This whale known as Al-Bal: sometimes chairs are made from the vertebrae of its back upon which a man sits and settles. They mentioned that in a village ten parasangs from Siraf known as Al-Tayin are ancient houses with small roofs made from the ribs of this whale. I heard someone say that in ancient days one of them fell near Siraf, so he went to look at it and found people climbing to its back with a small ladder. When the fishermen secure it, they cast it in the sun, cut its meat, and dig pits for it in which the grease (Wadak) «3» collects. It is scooped from its source when the sun melts the grease with heat. It is collected and sold to the masters of ships...

and mixed with mixtures of theirs with which sea ships are anointed to seal their seams. It also seals what splits of their seams, so the grease of this whale is sold for a sum of money. [Mention of Pearls] The beginning of the creation of the pearl is by the subtle management of Allah, blessed be His name, and He, Mighty and Majestic, says: (Glory be to Him who created all the pairs, of what the earth grows, and of themselves, and of what they do not know) «1». The pearl starts at the size of the Anjudhan seed «2», in its color, shape, smallness, lightness, thinness, and weakness. It flies on the face of the water, a weak flight, and falls on the sides of the divers' boats. Then it hardens over days, grows, and becomes stony. When it becomes heavy, it sticks to the bottom of the sea and feeds on what Allah knows best. There is nothing in it but a red piece of flesh like a tongue at its base; it has no bone, no nerve, and no vein in it. They have differed regarding the origin of the pearl. A group said: When rain falls, the oyster appears on the surface of the sea and opens its mouth so that rain drops into it, becoming a grain. Others said: It is generated from the oyster itself. This is the more correct of the two reports because it is sometimes found in the oyster while it is growing and has not detached, so it is plucked out. This is what the sea merchants call 'Al-Lu'lu' Al-Qal'' (Plucked Pearl), and Allah knows best. [Mention of the Pearls of Bahrain] Among the wonders we heard regarding the doors of provision: A Bedouin arrived at...

Basra in ancient days having with him a pearl grain worth a sum of money. He went with it to a perfumer he was familiar with, showed it to him, and asked him about it, not knowing its value. He informed him that it was a pearl. He said: 'What is its value?' He said: 'One hundred dirhams.' The Bedouin considered that a lot and said: 'Is there anyone who would buy it from me for what you said?' The perfumer paid him one hundred dirhams, and he bought provisions for his family with it. The beginning of the Sea of Fars, as we mentioned, is the Planks of Basra and the place known as Al-Kankala, which are signs set up of wood in the sea, trellised signs for ships to Oman. The distance is three hundred parasangs. Upon that is the coast of Fars and the lands of Bahrain. From Oman - and its capital is called Sinjar (Suhar?), and the Persians call it Marun (Mazun?) -...

...to Muscat [Muscat, Oman], which is a village of it where ship masters draw water from sweet wells there, is fifty parasangs. From Muscat to Ras al-Jumjumah [Ras al-Hadd?] is fifty parasangs. This is the end of the Sea of Fars, and its length is four hundred parasangs; this is the determination of sailors and ship masters. Ras al-Jumjumah is a mountain connected to the lands of Yemen from the land of Shihr [Ash Shihr, Yemen] and Al-Ahqaf. The sand of it is under the sea; its end in the water is not known where it terminates, I mean the mountain known as Ras al-Jumjumah. When what we described of the mountain is on land and some under the sea, it is called in the Roman Sea (Mediterranean) 'Al-Safalah' (The Shoal/Shelf). From that Safalah in the place known as the coast of Seleucia of the land of the Romans and its connection under the sea is towards the island of Cyprus. Upon it is the damage of most Roman ships and their destruction. We only express in the language of the people of every sea and what they use in their speech in what they know among themselves. From Ras al-Jumjumah ships launch to the Second Sea. From the Sea of Fars, which is known as Larwi, its bottom cannot be realized, nor can the multitude of its ends be counted, nor its limits controlled due to the abundance of its water and the vastness of its space. Many sailors claim that description cannot encompass its regions due to what we mentioned of its branching. Ships traverse it in two months, three, and in a month, according to the blowing of winds and safety. There is not in these seas, meaning what the Abyssinian Sea included, larger than this Sea of Larwi nor more severe. In its width is the Sea of Zanj and their lands. The ambergris of this sea is little. That is because ambergris mostly falls to the lands of Zanj and the coast of Shihr from...

...the land of the Arabs. The people of Shihr are people from Quda'a bin Malik bin Himyar and others of the Arabs. Those who inhabit this land of the Arabs are called Al-Mahrah [Mahra], people of hair and manes. Their language is contrary to the language of the Arabs; that is, they make Shin instead of Kaf. An example of that is their saying: 'Hal lash fima qultu li wa qultu lash an taj'ali alladhi ma'i fi alladhi ma'ash' (Do you have [an interest] in what I said to me [sic] and I said to you to put what is with me in what is with you), and other such speech and anecdotes of their talk. They are people of poverty and need. They have thoroughbred camels (Nujub) they ride at night known as the Mahrah Nujub; they resemble in speed the Beja Nujub, or rather according to a group they are faster than them. They travel on them on the coast of their sea. If these Nujub sense ambergris has been cast by the sea, they kneel on it, having been trained for that and accustomed to it, so the rider takes it. The best ambergris is what falls to this region and to the islands of Zanj and its coast. It is the round blue rare one like ostrich eggs or less than that. Among it is what the whale known as Al-Awal (Al-Wal/Whale), mentioned previously, swallows. That is because when the sea's agitation intensifies, it casts ambergris from its bottom like pieces of mountains or smaller as we described. If this whale swallows ambergris, it kills it, so it floats on the water. Therefore, people from Zanj and others watch for it in boats. They throw hooks and ropes into it, slit its belly, and extract the ambergris from it. What comes out of its belly is thick and perfumers in Iraq and Fars know it as Al-Nadd. What touched the back of the whale from it is pure and good according to its stay in the whale's belly. Between the Third Sea which is Harkand and the Second Sea which is Larwi as mentioned are many islands which are a separation between these two seas. It is said they are about...

...two thousand islands, and in the saying of the verifier one thousand nine hundred islands, all populated with people. The queen of all these islands is a woman; their custom has run like that from ancient times that no man rules them. Ambergris is found in these islands cast by the sea, and is found in its sea as large as pieces of rock can be. More than one of the Sirafi and Omani shipmasters in Oman and Siraf and other merchants who used to frequent these islands told me that ambergris grows at the bottom of this sea. It forms like the formation of types of mushrooms, white and black, truffles, and morels and the like. When the sea becomes malignant and intense, it casts from its bottom rocks, stones, and pieces of ambergris. The people of all these islands are united in word; numbers cannot count them due to their abundance, nor can the armies of this female ruler over them be counted. Between island and island is about a mile, a parasang, two parasangs, and three. Their palm trees are coconut palms; they do not miss anything from the palm tree except dates. Some people who concerned themselves with animal breeding and tree grafting claimed that this coconut is the Doum Palm (Muql), but the soil of India influenced it when it was planted there so it became coconut, while it is only the Doum Palm. We have mentioned in our book titled 'Book of Issues and Experiments' what every spot of the earth's spots and its air influences in its animals, speaking and others, and what spots influence in growing plants that are not growing [sic] like the donkey [? likely corruption, maybe referring to plants/animals]. Like the influence of the land of the Turks on their faces and the smallness of their eyes until that influenced their camels (jamal/jamalahum?), so their legs shortened, their necks thickened, and their fur whitened. And the land of Yajuj and Majuj (Gog and Magog) in their forms and other...

That is something that, if a person of knowledge investigates the inhabitants of the earth from the East and the West, he will find it as we mentioned. There is not found in the islands of the sea anyone with finer craftsmanship than the people of these islands in all trades and crafts, in clothes, tools, and other things. The treasuries of this queen are cowrie shells (Wada'), for the cowrie shell contains a type of animal. If her wealth decreases, she orders the people of these islands, and they cut palm branches of the coconut with their leaves and cast them on the face of the water. That animal piles up on them, then it is collected and cast upon the sand of the coast. The sun burns the animal inside it, and the cowrie shell remains empty of what was in it, and the treasuries are filled with that. All these islands are known as Al-Dabajat [Maldives/Laccadives], and from them, most of the Naranj—which is the coconut—is carried. The last of these islands is the Island of Sarandib [Sri Lanka]. Following Sarandib are other islands, about one thousand parasangs, known as Al-Ramni [Sumatra, Indonesia]; they are inhabited and have kings and many gold mines. Following them is the land of Fudur [Pansur/Barus, Sumatra], and to it, the Fuduri Camphor is attributed. In the year in which there are many thunderbolts, lightning, tremors, upheavals, and earthquakes, the camphor is abundant in it; and if that is little, its existence decreases. The food of most of those we mentioned in these islands is coconut. From these islands, Brazilwood (Baqqam), bamboo (Khayzuran), and gold are carried. Their elephants are many, and among them are those who eat human flesh. These islands connect to the Islands of Al-Najmalus [Nicobar Islands]. They are strange nations, naked; they come out in boats when ships pass by them carrying ambergris...

...and coconut and other things. They barter with iron and some clothes, and they do not sell that for dirhams or dinars. Following them are islands called Abraman [Andaman Islands], in which are black people of strange forms and appearances, with peppercorn hair. The foot of one of them is larger than a cubit. They have no boats. If a shipwrecked person from those broken in the sea falls to them, they eat him. Likewise is their action with ships if they fall to them. A group of Nakhudas (shipmasters) mentioned to me that they sometimes saw in this sea white clouds, small pieces, from which a long white tongue exits until it connects to the sea water. When it connects to it, the sea boils because of that, and great tornadoes (waterspouts) rise from it; no tornado from them passes by anything without destroying it. Following that, they rain a rain smelling of fish (Zahak), containing types of filth from the sea. As for the Fourth Sea, it is Kalah Bar [Kedah, Malaysia] according to what we mentioned, and the explanation of that is the Sea of Kalah. It is a sea with little water (shallow), and if the sea water is little, its calamities are more and its malice is more severe. It has many islands and 'Sara'ir'—singular is 'Sarr'—for the people of the ships call what is between the two gulfs, if their path is in it, 'Al-Sarr'. This sea has types of strange islands and mountains; our purpose is only to hint at flashes of news about them, not to elaborate. Likewise, the Fifth Sea known as Kardanj [Gulf of Thailand/South China Sea] has many mountains and islands; in it are camphor and camphor water. It has little water (shallow) and much rain, hardly ever free of it. In it are races of nations; among them is a race called the Fanjab, their hair is peppercorn-like and their forms are strange. They appear in boats; they have small [boats] for the ships when they pass by them, and they shoot a type of strange arrow that has been soaked in poison. Between this nation and the land of Kalah [Kedah] are mines of white lead (tin)...

...and mountains of silver. In it also are gold mines and lead that can hardly be distinguished. Then follows the Sea of Sanf [Champa/Vietnam] according to what we arranged previously. In it is the Kingdom of the Maharaja [Srivijaya], the King of the Islands. His kingdom cannot be defined due to its multitude, nor can his soldiers be counted. No one among people can tour his islands in the fastest of ships in two years. This king possesses types of spices and perfumes. No other king possesses what he has or what is exported from his lands. From his land are carried camphor, aloeswood, cloves, sandalwood, nutmeg, mace, cardamom, cubeb, and other things which we have not mentioned. His islands connect to a sea whose limit cannot be realized and whose end is not known, and it is adjacent to the Sea of China. In the extremities of his islands are many mountains in which are people with pierced ears, white faces like shields hammered out. They shear their hair as hair is sheared from a skin, in layers. Fire appears from their mountains by night and day; its day is red fire, and by night it turns black and reaches the clouds of the sky in its height and its going into the atmosphere, throwing out the most severe sounds of thunder and thunderbolts. Perhaps a strange, terrifying sound appears from it warning of the death of their king, and perhaps it is lower than that, warning of the death of some of their leaders. It has become known what that warns of due to the length of customs and experiences over ancient time, and that does not vary. This is one of the great wonders of the earth. Following it is the island from which is heard at all times the sounds of drums, oboes (Surnay), lutes, and all other types of delightful musical instruments. The rhythm of dancing and clapping is heard, and whoever hears that can distinguish between the sound of every type of delightful musical instrument and others.

The sailors among those who passed by those lands claim that the Dajjal (Antichrist) is in that island. In the Kingdom of the Maharaja is the Island of Sarira [Sumatra/Java?]; its distance in the sea is about four hundred parasangs, and its habitations are continuous. He has the islands of Al-Ranj and Al-Rami and others which cannot be fully mentioned among his islands and his kingdom. He is the master of the Sixth Sea, which is the Sea of Sanf. Then the Seventh Sea, which is the Sea of China [China] according to what we arranged previously. It is known as the Sea of Sanji. It is a malicious sea with many waves and 'Khabb'—and the explanation of Khabb is great severity in the sea. We only report the expression of the people of every sea and what they use in their speech. In it are many mountains (reefs/islands) between which ships must pass. That is because when the sea's Khabb becomes great and its waves numerous, black figures appear from it; the height of one of them is about five spans or four, as if they are the children of the Abyssinians, small, of one shape and one size. They climb onto the ships, and their climbing is frequent without harm. When people witness that, they become certain of the severity, for their appearance is a sign of the Khabb (storm), so they prepare for that—some afflicted and some safe. When that happens, perhaps the safe one sees—among them at the top of the mast (Daqal), and the masters of ships in the Sea of China and elsewhere call it Daqal, and the men of the Roman Sea [Mediterranean] call it Sari—something in the image of a bird, kindling and glowing. The onlooker among them cannot look at it fully nor perceive how it is. If it settles on the top of the mast, they see the sea calm down, the waves become small, and the Khabb subside. Then that light vanishes, and it is not known how it came or how it went. That is the sign of salvation and the proof of rescue. What we mentioned is not denied by the people of the ships and the merchants from the people of Basra [Basra, Iraq], Siraf [Bandar Siraf, Iran], and Oman [Oman]...

...and others who have traversed these seas. What we mentioned from them is possible, not impossible, nor obligatory, since it is permissible within the power of the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, to save His servants from destruction and rescue them from tribulation. In this sea is a type of crab that comes out of the sea like a cubit, a span, smaller than that, or larger. When it leaves the water with a quick movement and gets on the land, it becomes stone, and the animal nature departs from it. Those stones enter into eye kohls and medicines, and its matter is also well-known. After the land of China towards the sea, there are no known kingdoms or described lands except the land of Al-Sila [Silla/Korea] and its islands. No one from the strangers from Iraq or elsewhere reached it and left it, due to the health of its air, the thinness (purity) of its water, the goodness of its soil, and the abundance of its good things, except for rare people. Its people are in a truce with the people of China and its kings, and gifts from them hardly cease. It has been said that they are a tribe from the children of Amur who settled there according to what we mentioned about the settlement of the people of China in their lands. China has large rivers like the Tigris and the Euphrates flowing from the lands of the Turk [Turkic lands], Tibet [Tibet], and Al-Sogd [Sogdia], who are between Bukhara [Bukhara, Uzbekistan] and Samarkand [Samarkand, Uzbekistan]. There are the mountains of Nushadir (Sal Ammoniac). If it is summer, you see fires at night rising from those mountains from about one hundred parasangs. By day, smoke appears from them, overcome by the rays of the sun, its light, and the light of day. From there Nushadir is carried. If it is the beginning of winter, whoever wants from the land of Khorasan to travel to the land of China goes to what is there. There is a valley between those mountains whose length is forty miles or fifty miles. He comes to people there at the mouth of the valley and encourages them with a precious wage, so they carry what is with him...

...on their shoulders. In their hands are sticks with which they beat his sides for fear that he might freeze and stop, then die from the distress of the valley. He runs in front of them until they exit to that head of the valley. There are forests and swamps belonging to it, so they throw themselves into that water because of the severity of the distress and the heat of the Nushadir that has afflicted them. No animals travel that road because the Nushadir flares up as fire in the summer, so no caller or answerer travels that valley. When it is winter and snows and moisture are abundant, that falls on the place and extinguishes the heat of the Nushadir and its flame. People then travel that valley. Animals have no patience for what we mentioned of its heat. Likewise, whoever arrives from the land of China, the beating is done to him just as is done to the passerby. The distance between the land of Khorasan [Khorasan] at the place we mentioned to the land of China is about forty days between inhabited and uninhabited lands, soft ground, and sands. In other than this road which animals travel, it is about four months, except that it is under the protection of types of Turks. I saw in Balkh [Balkh, Afghanistan] a handsome sheikh of opinion and understanding who had entered China many times and never rode the sea. I saw a number of people who traveled from the land of Al-Sogd over the mountains of Nushadir to the land of Tibet and China in the land of Khorasan. The land of India is connected to the land of Khorasan and Al-Sindh [Sindh, Pakistan] adjacent to Al-Mansura [Mansura, Pakistan] and Al-Multan [Multan, Pakistan]. Caravans are continuous from Al-Sindh to Khorasan, and likewise to India, until these lands connect to the land of Zabilistan [Zabulistan].
